revision.text:
{{short description|German-born American-New Zealand entrepreneur, venture capitalist, and hedge fund manager}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox person |name = Peter Thiel |image = Peter Thiel 2014 by Heisenberg Media.jpg |caption = Peter Thiel, 2014 |alt = Man in his 40s with short, dark hair wearing a shirt and blazer |birth_name = Peter Andreas Thiel |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1967|10|11}} |birth_place = [[Frankfurt]], [[West Germany]] |death_date = |death_place = |citizenship = {{plainlist| *Germany (1967–present) *United States (1978–present) *New Zealand (2011–present)}} |education = [[Stanford University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]<ref name=DW>{{Cite news|url=https://www.weltwoche.ch/ausgaben/2018-29/artikel/en-hypnotische-massenphanomene-die-weltwoche-ausgabe-29-2018.html|title=Interview of the Week: Peter Thiel|last=Schwab|first=Florian|date=|work=Die Weltwoche|access-date=July 23, 2018}}</ref> |occupation = {{plainlist| *President of [[Clarium Capital]] *Chairman of [[Palantir Technologies|Palantir]] *Board member of [[Facebook]] *Partner in [[Founders Fund]] *Chairman of [[Valar Ventures]] *Chair of Mithril Capital}} |networth = {{nowrap|[[US$]]2.5 billion (February 2018)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/peter-thiel/|title=Peter Thiel|website =Forbes|author =Staff writer(s)|date =February 21, 2018}}</ref>}} |spouse = {{married|Matt Danzeisen|October 2017}} }}
'''Peter Andreas Thiel''' ({{IPAc-en|t|iː|l}}; born October 11, 1967) is an American<!-- Per MOS:BLPLEAD, "previous nationalities or the country of birth should not be mentioned in the lead unless they are relevant to the subject's notability." --> entrepreneur, venture capitalist, philanthropist, political activist, and author. He is a co-founder of [[PayPal]], [[Palantir Technologies]] and [[Founders Fund]]. He was ranked No. 4 on the [[Midas List|''Forbes'' Midas List]] of 2014, with a net worth of $2.2 billion, and No. 315 on the [[Forbes 400|''Forbes'' 400]] in 2017, with a net worth of $2.6 billion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Midas List 2014: The Billionaires|url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/emii45hfff/peter-thiel-2/|author=Staff writer(s)|website=Forbes|date=April 3, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Peter Thiel profile|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/peter-thiel/?list=forbes-400|website=Forbes|accessdate=20 October 2017}}</ref>
Thiel was born in [[Frankfurt]], and holds German citizenship. He moved with his family to the United States as an infant, and spent a portion of his upbringing in Africa before returning to the United States. He studied philosophy at [[Stanford University]], graduating with a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in 1989. He then went on to the [[Stanford Law School]], and received his [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] in 1992. After graduation, he worked as a [[judicial clerk]] for Judge [[James Larry Edmondson]], a [[security (finance)|securities]] lawyer for [[Sullivan & Cromwell]], a speechwriter for former-[[United States Secretary of Education|U.S. Secretary of Education]] [[William Bennett]] and as a [[Derivative (finance)|derivatives]] trader at [[Credit Suisse]] prior to founding Thiel Capital in 1996. He co-founded [[PayPal]] in 1999, serving as [[chief executive officer]] until its sale to [[eBay]] in 2002 for $1.5 billion.
After the sale of PayPal, he founded [[Clarium Capital]], a [[global macro]] [[hedge fund]]. He launched [[Palantir Technologies]], a [[big data]] analysis company, in 2004 and continues to serve as its chairman as of 2018. His [[Founders Fund]], a [[venture capital]] firm, was launched in 2005 along with PayPal partners [[Ken Howery]] and [[Luke Nosek]]. Earlier, Thiel became [[Facebook]]'s first outside investor when he acquired a 10.2% stake for $500,000 in August 2004. He sold the majority of his shares in Facebook for over $1 billion in 2012, but remains on the board of directors. He also co-founded [[Valar Ventures]] in 2010 and operates as its chairman, co-founded Mithril Capital, of which he is investment committee chair, in 2012, and served as a partner at [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]] from 2015 to 2017.<ref name=PayPalMafia>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/11106473/The-PayPal-Mafia-Who-are-they-and-where-are-Silicon-Valleys-richest-group-of-men-now.html|title = The PayPal Mafia: Who are they and where are Silicon Valley's richest group of men now?|publisher = [[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate = 2014-09-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/8537d776-664f-11e3-aa10-00144feabdc0|title=Lunch with the FT: Peter Thiel|first=Richard|last=Waters|website=[[Financial Times]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/c2dcf2be-a850-11e6-8898-79a99e2a4de6|title=Tech elite discovers it may need Peter Thiel|first=Leslie|last=Hook|website=[[Financial Times]]}}</ref>
Through the [[Thiel Foundation]], Thiel governs the grant-making bodies [[Breakout Labs]] and [[Thiel Fellowship]], and funds nonprofit research into [[artificial intelligence]], [[life extension]] and [[seasteading]]. A co-founder of ''[[The Stanford Review]]'', he is a [[Libertarian conservatism|conservative libertarian]] who is critical of high government spending, high debt levels, and foreign wars. He has donated to numerous political figures. In 2016, Thiel revealed that he had funded [[Hulk Hogan]] in the ''[[Bollea v. Gawker]]'' lawsuit, which ultimately led to the bankruptcy of [[Gawker]].
==Early life==
===Childhood=== Peter Andreas Thiel was born in [[Frankfurt|Frankfurt am Main]], [[West Germany]] on October 11, 1967 to Susanne and Klaus Friedrich Thiel.<ref>O'Dea, Meghan. [http://www.immigrantentrepreneurship.org/entry.php?rec=246 "Peter Thiel."] In ''Immigrant Entrepreneurship: German-American Business Biographies, 1720 to the Present'', vol. 5, edited by R. Daniel Wadhwani. German Historical Institute. Last modified July 24, 2015.</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.dia.govt.nz/diawebsite.nsf/Files/Peter-Thiel-release-1-February-2017/$file/Peter-Thiel-release-1-February-2017.pdf|title=Peter Thiel's application for New Zealand citizenship|last=|first=|date=|website=New Zealand Department of Internal Affairs|page=65|access-date=}}</ref> The family migrated to the [[United States]] when Peter was age one and lived in [[Cleveland]], where Klaus worked as a [[chemical engineer]]. Klaus then worked for various mining companies, which caused an itinerant upbringing for Thiel and his younger brother, Patrick Michael Thiel.<ref name=bloomberg>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-02-03/peter-thiel-21st-century-free-radical|first=Romesh|last=Ratnesar|title=Peter Thiel: 21st Century Free Radical|website=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|date=February 3, 2011|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Thiel|first1=Peter|title=Peter Thiel, technology entrepreneur and investor. AMA|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/2g4g95/peter_thiel_technology_entrepreneur_and_investor/ckfoeji|website=[[Reddit]]|accessdate=September 11, 2014}}</ref> Thiel's mother naturalized as a U.S. citizen but his father did not.<ref name=":0" />
Before settling in [[Foster City, California]] in 1977, the Thiels had lived in [[South Africa]] and [[South West Africa]] (modern-day [[Namibia]]), and Peter had to change elementary schools seven times. One of Peter's elementary schools, a strict establishment in [[Swakopmund]], required students to wear uniforms and utilized [[corporal punishment]], such as striking students' hands with a ruler for mistakes. This experience instilled a distaste for uniformity and regimentation later reflected in Thiel's support for [[individualism]] and [[libertarianism]] as an adult.<ref>{{harvnb|Packer|2013|pages=120–121}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704696304575537882643165738|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|title=Technology=Salvation|last=Jenkins, Jr.|first=Holman W.|date=October 9, 2010|accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref>
Thiel played ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', was an avid reader of [[science fiction]], with [[Isaac Asimov]] and [[Robert A. Heinlein]] among his favorite authors, and a fan of [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s works, stating as an adult that he had read ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' over ten times during his childhood.<ref name=Brown2014>{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Mick|title=Peter Thiel: the billionaire tech entrepreneur on a mission to cheat death|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/11098971/Peter-Thiel-the-billionaire-tech-entrepreneur-on-a-mission-to-cheat-death.html|accessdate=October 16, 2014|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=September 19, 2014}}</ref> He has since founded 6 firms ([[Palantir Technologies]], [[Valar Ventures]], Mithril Capital, Lembas LLC, Rivendell LLC and Arda Capital) whose names originate from Tolkien.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-38315682|title=Who is Peter Thiel and why is he advising Donald Trump?|agency=BBC News|date=December 14, 2016}}</ref>
===Education=== Thiel excelled in [[mathematics]], and scored first in a California-wide mathematics competition while attending middle school in [[San Mateo, California|San Mateo]].<ref name=contrarian/> At the [[San Mateo High School]], he read [[Ayn Rand]], admired the [[optimism]] and [[anti-communism]] of then-President [[Ronald Reagan]], and was [[valedictorian]] of his graduating class in 1985.<ref name=contrarian/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abc7news.com/technology/only-on-abc7-billionaire-weighs-in-on-silicon-valleys-future/320291/|first=Ama|last=Daetz|title=Billionaire weighs in on Silicon Valley's future|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=September 22, 2014|accessdate=November 18, 2016}}</ref>
After graduating from San Mateo High School, Thiel went on to study [[philosophy]] at [[Stanford University]]. During Thiel's time at Stanford, debates on [[identity politics]] and [[political correctness]] were ongoing at the university. A "[[Western Culture]]" program, which was criticized by ''[[The Rainbow Agenda]]'' because of a perceived over-representation of the achievements made by European men, was replaced with a "Culture, Ideas and Values" course, which instead pushed diversity and [[multiculturalism]]. This replacement provoked controversy on the campus, and led to Thiel founding ''[[The Stanford Review]]'', a paper for [[conservatism|conservative]] and [[libertarianism|libertarian]] viewpoints, in 1987, through the funding of [[Irving Kristol]].<ref>{{harvnb|Packer|2013|page=125}}</ref>
Thiel served as ''The Stanford Review's'' first [[editor-in-chief]] and remained in that post until he received his [[Bachelor of Arts]] in 1989, at which point his friend [[David O. Sacks]] became the new editor-in-chief.<ref>{{cite book|first=Mohammad|last=Bahareth|title=Kings of the Internet: What You Don't Know About Them?|publisher=iUniverse|date=2012|isbn=978-1469798424|page=71}}</ref> Thiel then continued on to the [[Stanford Law School]] and acquired his [[Juris Doctor|Doctor of Jurisprudence]] in 1992.<ref name="Paypal,-Inc-Jan-2002-S-1/A">{{cite web|url=http://edgar.secdatabase.com/2504/91205702003491/filing-main.htm |title=Paypal, Inc, Form S-1/A, Filing Date Jan 31, 2002 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =May 14, 2018}}</ref>
While at Stanford, Thiel met [[René Girard]], whose [[René Girard#Mimetic desire|mimetic theory]] influenced him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://businessinsider.com/peter-thiel-on-rene-girards-influence-2014-11|first=Richard|last=Feloni|title=Peter Thiel explains how an esoteric philosophy book shaped his worldview|website=[[Business Insider]]|date=November 10, 2014|accessdate=November 22, 2016}}</ref> Mimetic theory posits that human behavior is based upon [[mimesis]], and that imitation can engender pointless conflict. Girard notes the productive potential of competition: "It is because of this unprecedented capacity to promote competition within limits that always remain socially, if not individually, acceptable that we have all the amazing achievements of the modern world," but states that competition stifles progress once it becomes an end in itself: "rivals are more apt to forget about whatever objects are the cause of the rivalry and instead become more fascinated with one another."<ref>{{cite book|first=René|last=Girard|title=Things Hidden Since the Foundation of the World|publisher=Stanford University Press|date=1987|pages=7, 26, 307}}</ref> Thiel applied this theory to his personal life and business ventures, stating: "The big problem with competition is that it focuses us on the people around us, and while we get better at the things we're competing on, we lose sight of anything that's important, or [[Transcendentalism|transcendent]], or truly meaningful in our world."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://businessinsider.com/peter-thiel-advice-to-younger-self-2015-2|first=Drake|last=Baer|title=Here's the advice billionaire investor Peter Thiel wishes he could've given his younger self|website=[[Business Insider]]|date=February 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/peter-thiel-competition-is-for-losers-1410535536|first=Peter|last=Thiel|title=Competition Is for Losers|website=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=September 12, 2014}}</ref>
==Career==
===Early career=== After graduating Stanford Law School, Thiel clerked for Judge [[James Larry Edmondson]] of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/09/15/trump-thiel-supreme-court/|title=Rumor About Trump's Supreme Court Pick Causes a Stir But Appears Untrue|first=Jeff John|last=Roberts|website=Fortune|date=September 15, 2016}}</ref> After his clerkship with Judge Edmondson, Thiel worked as a [[Security (finance)|securities]] lawyer for [[Sullivan & Cromwell]] in New York. After seven months and three days, he left the law firm citing a lack of transcendental value in his work.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://stanfordlawyer.law.stanford.edu/2011/05/q-a-legal-matters-with-peter-thiel-%E2%80%9992-ba-%E2%80%9989-bs-%E2%80%9989-and-mark-a-lemley-ba-%E2%80%9988/|title=Articles Archive - Stanford Law School|author=Stanford Law School|publisher=|accessdate=May 29, 2016}}</ref> He then took a job as a [[Derivative (finance)|derivatives]] trader in currency options at [[Credit Suisse]], working there from 1993 on while also operating as a speechwriter for former-[[United States Secretary of Education]] [[William Bennett]], before again feeling as though his work lacked meaningful value and returning to California in 1996.<ref name="BW01">Hibbard, Justin, [https://www.bloomberg.com/bw/stories/2004-11-07/big-bucks-from-bubble-fears "Big Bucks From Bubble Fears"], ''Business Week'', November 8, 2004. Retrieved 2015-07-27.</ref>
Upon returning to the [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]], Thiel noticed that the development of the [[internet]] and [[personal computer]] had already altered the economic landscape and the [[dot-com boom]] was well underway. With financial support from friends and family, he was able to raise $1 million toward the establishment of Thiel Capital Management and embark on his venture capital career. Early on, he experienced a setback after investing $100,000 in his friend [[Luke Nosek]]'s unsuccessful web-based calendar project. However, his luck changed when [[Max Levchin]], a friend of Nosek's, introduced him to his [[cryptography]]-related company idea, which later became their first venture called [[Confinity]] in 1998.
===PayPal=== {{further|PayPal#Early history}} With Confinity, Thiel realized they could develop software to solve a gap in making online payments. Although the use of [[credit card]]s and expanding [[Cash machine|automated teller machine]] networks provided consumers with more available payment options, not all merchants could gain the necessary hardware to accept credit cards. Thus, consumers were often left with little choice and instead had to pay with exact cash or personal checks. Thiel wanted to create a type of digital wallet in the hopes of ensuring more consumer convenience and security by encrypting data on digital devices, and in 1999 Confinity launched [[PayPal]].
PayPal promised to open up new possibilities for handling money, and according to [[Eric M. Jackson]]'s account in his book ''[[The PayPal Wars]]'', Thiel viewed PayPal's mission as liberating people throughout the world from the erosion of the value of their currencies due to [[inflation]]. Jackson recalls an inspirational speech by Thiel in 1999:
{{quote|We're definitely onto something big. The need PayPal answers is monumental. Everyone in the world needs money – to get paid, to trade, to live. Paper money is an ancient technology and an inconvenient means of payment. You can run out of it. It wears out. It can get lost or stolen. In the twenty-first century, people need a form of money that's more convenient and secure, something that can be accessed from anywhere with a PDA or an Internet connection. Of course, what we're calling 'convenient' for American users will be revolutionary for the developing world. Many of these countries' governments play fast and loose with their currencies. They use inflation and sometimes wholesale currency devaluations, like we saw in Russia and several Southeast Asian countries last year [referring to the [[1998 Russian financial crisis|1998 Russian]] and [[1997 Asian financial crisis]]], to take wealth away from their citizens. Most of the ordinary people there never have an opportunity to open an offshore account or to get their hands on more than a few bills of a stable currency like U.S. dollars. Eventually PayPal will be able to change this. In the future, when we make our service available outside the U.S. and as Internet penetration continues to expand to all economic tiers of people, PayPal will give citizens worldwide more direct control over their currencies than they ever had before. It will be nearly impossible for corrupt governments to steal wealth from their people through their old means because if they try the people will switch to dollars or Pounds or Yen, in effect dumping the worthless local currency for something more secure.<ref>{{cite book|first=Eric M.|last=Jackson|title=[[The PayPal Wars]]|date=2004|page=Kindle Locations 321–327}}</ref>}}
When PayPal launched at a successful press conference in 1999, representatives from [[Nokia]] and [[Deutsche Bank]] sent $3 million in venture funding to Thiel using PayPal on their [[PalmPilot]]s. PayPal then continued to grow through mergers with [[Elon Musk]]'s financial services company, X.com, and with [[Pixo]], a company specializing in mobile commerce, in 2000. These mergers allowed PayPal to expand into the wireless phone market, and transformed it into a safer and more user-friendly tool by enabling users to transfer money via a free online registration and email rather than by exchanging bank account information.
PayPal [[Initial public offering|went public]] on February 15, 2002 and was sold to [[eBay]] for $1.5 billion in October of that year.<ref>{{cite web|title=eBay picks up PayPal for $1.5 billion by Margaret Kane|CNET News.com|accessdate=2008-01-24|url=http://www.news.com/2100-1017-941964.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ZJ3x0dGI?url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1017-941964.html?hhTest=1|archivedate=July 14, 2008|quote=On Monday, eBay said it is acquiring online payments company PayPal in a deal valued at $1.5 billion.|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Thiel remained CEO of the company until the sale.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-who-is-peter-thiel-20180215-story.html|title=Peter Thiel's resume includes PayPal, Facebook and supporting Trump. And he's coming to L.A.|last=Lien|first=Tracey|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref> His 3.7% stake in the company was worth $55 million at the time of acquisition.<ref>{{cite web|title=SEC Info – Ebay Inc – S-4 – on 8/6/02|accessdate=2008-01-24|url=http://www.secinfo.com/dr6nd.33fd.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061214082119/http://www.secinfo.com/dr6nd.33fd.htm|dead-url=no|archivedate=2006-12-14}}</ref> In Silicon Valley circles, Thiel is colloquially referred to as the "Don of the [[PayPal Mafia]]".<ref>{{Cite news|title=The PayPal mafia – November 14, 2007|accessdate=2008-01-24|url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/11/13/magazines/fortune/paypal_mafia.fortune/index.htm|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5aLZvKSWi?url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/11/13/magazines/fortune/paypal_mafia.fortune/index.htm|archivedate=August 25, 2008|work=CNN|date=2007-11-14|first=Jeffrey M.|last=O'Brien|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Clarium Capital=== {{further|Clarium Capital}} Following PayPal's sale to eBay in 2002, Thiel devoted $10 million of his proceeds to establish [[Clarium Capital Management]], a [[global macro]] [[hedge fund]] focusing on directional and liquid instruments in currencies, interest rates, commodities, and equities. Thiel stated that "the big, macroeconomic idea that we had at Clarium—the [[Idée fixe (psychology)|idée fixe]]—was the [[Hubbert peak theory|peak-oil theory]], which was basically that the world was running out of oil, and that there were no easy alternatives."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2014/09/04/peter-thiels-contrarian-strategy/|title=Peter Thiel disagrees with you|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-08-17|language=en}}</ref>
In 2003, Clarium Capital reflected a return of 65.6% as Thiel successfully bet that the [[United States dollar]] would weaken.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/peter-thiel-facebook-trump-biography-2018-2#when-paypal-was-sold-in-2002-thiels-stake-was-worth-about-55-million-which-he-used-to-launch-a-hedge-fund-clarium-capital-by-the-time-he-was-37-clarium-was-managing-270-million-8|title=The life and rise of billionaire investor Peter Thiel, Trump’s biggest Silicon Valley supporter — who might be moving to Los Angeles|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-08-17}}</ref> In 2004, Thiel spoke of the [[dot-com bubble]] having migrated, in effect, into a growing bubble in the financial sector, and specified [[General Electric]] and [[Walmart]] as vulnerable. In 2005, Clarium saw a 57.1% return<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB113961793285971352|title=A Second Payday for PayPal Founder|last=Savitz|first=Eric J.|date=2006-02-13|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-08-17|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> as Thiel predicted that the dollar would rally.<ref name=":1" /> This success saw Clarium honored as global macro hedge fund of the year by ''[[MARHedge]]'' and ''[[Absolute Return + Alpha]].''{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
However, Clarium faltered in 2006 with a 7.8% loss. During this time, the firm sought to profit in the long-term from its petrodollar analysis, which foresaw the impending decline in oil supplies and the unsustainable bubble growing in the U.S. housing market. Clarium's [[assets under management]] indeed, after achieving a 40.3% return in 2007, grew to over $7 billion by 2008, but plummeted as financial markets collapsed near the start of 2009. By 2011, after missing out on the economic rebound, many key investors pulled out, causing Clarium's assets to be valued at $350 million, over half of which was Thiel's own money.<ref name=newyorker>{{cite web|title=No Death, No Taxes: The libertarian futurism of a Silicon Valley billionaire.|accessdate=2011-12-07|first=George|last=Packer|publisher=[[The New Yorker]]|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2011/11/28/111128fa_fact_packer?currentpage=all}}</ref>
===Palantir=== {{further|Palantir Technologies}} In May 2003, Thiel incorporated Palantir Technologies, a [[big data]] [[data analysis|analysis]] company named after the [[Palantír|Tolkien artifact]], and continues to serve as its chairman as of 2018. Thiel stated that the idea for the company was based on the realization that "the approaches that PayPal had used to fight fraud could be extended into other contexts, like fighting terrorism." He also stated that, after the [[September 11 attacks]], the debate in the United States was "will we have more security with less privacy or less security with more privacy?" and saw Palantir as being able to provide [[data mining]] services to government intelligence agencies which were maximally unintrusive and traceable.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/palantir-the-vanguard-of-cyberterror-security-11222011.html |title=Palantir, the War on Terror's Secret Weapon}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/08/14/agent-of-intelligence-how-a-deviant-philosopher-built-palantir-a-cia-funded-data-mining-juggernaut/2/|title=How A 'Deviant' Philosopher Built Palantir, A CIA-Funded Data-Mining Juggernaut|author=Andy Greenberg|work=Forbes|accessdate=June 7, 2015}}</ref>
At first, Palantir's only backers were the [[Central Intelligence Agency]]'s [[venture capital]] arm [[In-Q-Tel]], but the company steadily grew and in 2015 was valued at $20 billion, with Thiel being the company's largest shareholder.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ryanmac/2014/12/11/palantir-aiming-to-raise-400-million-in-new-round/#17d326062a06|first=Ryan|last=Mac|title=Palantir Aiming To Raise $400 Million In New Round|website=Forbes|date=December 11, 2014|accessdate=December 21, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/12/23/palantir-has-raised-880-million-at-a-20-billion-valuation/|title=Palantir Has Raised $880 Million At A $20 Billion Valuation|first=Sarah|last=Buhr|website=[[TechCrunch]]|date=December 23, 2015|accessdate=December 14, 2016}}</ref>
===Facebook=== {{further|Facebook#Thefacebook, Thiel investment, and name change}} In August 2004, Thiel made a $500,000 [[Angel investor|angel investment]] in [[Facebook]] for a 10.2% stake in the company and joined Facebook's board. This was the first outside investment in Facebook, and put the valuation of the company at $4.9 million.<ref name="G01">[https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2010/aug/25/facebook-value-flotation "Shareholder trading values Facebook at more than $33bn" The Guardian – August 25, 2010:] This reference does not confirm Thiel's percentage stake, implied to be 5.2% i.e. 33 divided by 1.7. The 5.2% is also independently asserted in the Facebook section of this Wikipedia article, but without citation. The imputed valuation of Facebook has, also, moved up to $50bn in an early-2011 transaction with [[Goldman Sachs]] (Craig, Susanne and [[Andrew Ross Sorkin]], [https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2011/01/02/goldman-invests-in-facebook-at-50-billion-valuation/ "Goldman Offering Clients a Chance to Invest in Facebook"], ''The New York Times'' Dealbook, January 2, 2011.) A 5.2% share of $50 billion would be worth $2.58 billion. For its part, by March 2010, Forbes had actually reduced its estimate of Thiel's net worth to $1.2 billion ([https://www.forbes.com/lists/2010/10/billionaires-2010_Peter-Thiel_J5T8.html #828 on list of world's billionaires]), though the higher Facebook valuation makes this even more undervalued. Footnote expanded 2011-01-11.</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Life After Facebook |first=Brian |last=Caulfield |first2=Nicole |last2=Perlroth |url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2011/0214/features-peter-thiel-social-media-life-after-facebook_3.html |work=[[Forbes]] |date=February 14, 2011 |accessdate=November 29, 2011}}</ref> As a board member, Thiel was not actively involved in Facebook's day-to-day running. However, he did provide help with timing the various rounds of funding and Zuckerberg credited Thiel with helping him time Facebook's 2007 Series D to close before the [[Financial crisis of 2007–08|2008 financial crisis]].<ref>Kirkpatrick, David (2010-06-08). The Facebook Effect (p. 246). Simon & Schuster. Kindle Edition.</ref>
In his book ''[[The Facebook Effect]]'', [[David Kirkpatrick (author)|David Kirkpatrick]] outlines how Thiel came to make this investment: [[Napster]] co-founder [[Sean Parker]], who at the time had assumed the title of "President" of Facebook, was seeking investors for Facebook. Parker approached [[Reid Hoffman]], the CEO of work-based social network [[LinkedIn]]. Hoffman liked Facebook but declined to be the lead investor because of the potential for conflict of interest with his duties as LinkedIn CEO. Thus, Hoffman directed Parker to Thiel, whom he knew from their [[PayPal]] days. Thiel met Parker and [[Mark Zuckerberg]], the Harvard student who had founded Facebook. Thiel and Zuckerberg got along well and Thiel agreed to lead Facebook's [[Venture round|seed round]] with $500,000 for 10.2% of the company. The investment was originally in the form of a [[convertible note]], to be converted to equity if Facebook reached 1.5 million users by the end of 2004. Although Facebook narrowly missed the target, Thiel allowed the loan to be converted to equity anyway.<ref name=kirkpatrick-thiel>{{cite book|first=David|last=Kirkpatrick|date=2010|title=The Facebook Effect|pp=87–8|publisher=Simon & Schuster}}</ref> Thiel said of his investment:
<blockquote>I was comfortable with them pursuing their original vision. And it was a very reasonable valuation. I thought it was going to be a pretty safe investment.<ref name=kirkpatrick-thiel/></blockquote>
In September 2010, Thiel, while expressing skepticism about the potential for growth in the consumer Internet sector, argued that relative to other Internet companies, Facebook (which then had a secondary market valuation of $30 billion) was comparatively undervalued.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allthingsd.com/20100928/peter-thiel-why-facebook-is-like-ford-motors-in-the-1920s/|title = Peter Thiel: Why Facebook Is Like Ford Motors In The 1920s}}</ref>
Facebook's [[initial public offering]] was in May 2012, with a market cap of nearly $100 billion ($38 a share), at which time Thiel sold 16.8 million shares for $638 million.<ref name=betabeat>Tiku, Nitasha. (2013-01-19) [http://betabeat.com/2012/08/peter-thiel-sells-almost-all-facebook-stock-tea-party-donation-08202012/ Peter Thiel Sells Almost All of His Facebook Stock, Donates $1 Million to a Tea Party PAC]. Betabeat. Retrieved on 2013-10-23.</ref> In August 2012, immediately upon the conclusion of the early investor lock out period, Thiel sold almost all of his remaining stake for between $19.27 and $20.69 per share, or $395.8 million, for a total of more than $1 billion.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-facebook-thiel-idUSBRE87J0UQ20120820 |title=Facebook director Thiel sold 20 million shares after lock-up |publisher=Reuters |author=Alexei Oreskovic |date=August 19, 2012 |accessdate=August 19, 2012}}</ref> He retained his seat on the board of directors.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/48730344 |title=Investor Peter Thiel Sells Facebook Shares |date=August 20, 2012 |author=Julia Boorstin |publisher=CNBC |accessdate=August 20, 2012}}</ref> In 2016 he sold a little under 1 million of his shares for around $100 million. In November 2017 he sold another 160,805 shares for $29 million, putting his holdings in Facebook at 59,913 Class A shares.<ref>{{cite web|url =https://www.reuters.com/article/us-facebook-stake/peter-thiel-sells-most-of-remaining-facebook-stake-idUSKBN1DM2BQ|title =Peter Thiel sells most of remaining Facebook stake|author =Reuters Staff|publisher =Reuters|date =November 22, 2017}}</ref>
===Founders Fund=== {{further|Founders Fund}} In 2005, Thiel created Founders Fund, a San Francisco-based venture capital fund. Other partners in the fund include [[Sean Parker]], [[Ken Howery]], and [[Luke Nosek]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/249705|title=What Types of Companies Is Peter Thiel's Founders Fund Actually Investing In?|last=Siu|first=Eric|date=2015-08-25|work=Entrepreneur|access-date=2018-04-11|language=en}}</ref>
In addition to Facebook, Thiel has made early-stage investments in numerous startups (personally or through his venture capital fund), including [[Booktrack]], [[Slide.com|Slide]], [[LinkedIn]], [[Friendster]], [[Rapleaf]], [[Geni.com]], [[Yammer]], [[Yelp Inc.]], [[Powerset (company)|Powerset]], [[Practice Fusion]], [[MetaMed]], [[Vator]], [[Palantir Technologies]], [[IronPort]], [[Votizen]], [[Asana (web application)|Asana]], [[Big Think]], Caplinked, [[Quora]], [[Nanotronics Imaging]], [[Rypple]], [[TransferWise]], [[Stripe (company)|Stripe]], and Block.one (the publisher of the [[EOS.IO]] [[blockchain]] protocol).<ref>{{cite web|title = Block.one Closes Strategic Investment Round Led by Peter Thiel and Bitmain|url=https://block.one/news/block-one-closes-strategic-investment-round-led-by-peter-thiel-and-bitmain/}}</ref>{{primary source inline|date=November 2018}} Slide, LinkedIn, Yelp, Geni.com, and [[Yammer]] were founded by Thiel's former colleagues at PayPal: Slide by [[Max Levchin]], Linkedin by [[Reid Hoffman]], Yelp by [[Jeremy Stoppelman]], and Geni.com and Yammer by [[David O. Sacks]]. ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine reports that PayPal alumni have founded or invested in dozens of startups with an aggregate value of around $30 billion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2007/11/13/paypal-mafia/|title=The PayPal Mafia|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-04-11|language=en}}</ref>
In mid-2017 Founders Fund bought $15–20 million worth of [[bitcoin]]. In January 2018 the venture capital firm told investors that due to the cryptocurrency's surge the holdings were worth hundreds of millions of dollars.<ref>{{cite web|url =https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/02/bitcoin-rises-after-report-says-early-facebook-investor-peter-thiel-is-buying-massive-amounts.html|title =Bitcoin rises after report says early Facebook investor Peter Thiel is buying massive amounts|first =Evelyn|last= Cheng|publisher =CNBC|date =2 January 2018}}</ref>
===Valar Ventures=== {{further|Valar Ventures}} Through Valar Ventures, an internationally focused venture firm he cofounded with Andrew McCormack and James Fitzgerald,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gobry|first1=Pascal-Emmanuel|title=Billionaire Facebook Investor Peter Thiel Pours Money Into His "Utopia," New Zealand|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/peter-thiel-new-zealand-2011-1|accessdate=August 21, 2014|agency=Business Insider|date=January 14, 2011}}</ref> Thiel was also an early investor in [[Xero (software)|Xero]], a software firm headquartered in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Drury|first1=Rod|title=Peter Thiel to Invest in Xero|url=http://www.xero.com/blog/2010/10/peter-thiel-to-invest-in-xero/|website=Xero|publisher=Xero|accessdate=August 21, 2014}}</ref> He also invested in [[Pacific Fibre]].<ref name=BI>Pascal Emmanuel-Gobry,[https://www.businessinsider.com.au/peter-thiel-new-zealand-2011-1?r=US&IR=T ''Billionaire Facebook Investor Peter Thiel Pours Money Into His "Utopia," New Zealand''], 15 January 2011</ref>
===Mithril Capital=== In June 2012, Peter Thiel launched Mithril Capital Management, named after [[Mithril|the fictitious metal]] in ''The Lord of the Rings'', with Jim O'Neill and Ajay Royan. Unlike Clarium Capital, Mithril Capital, a fund with $402 million at the time of launch, targets companies that are beyond the startup stage and ready to scale up.<ref name=latimes-mithril>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/money/la-fi-mo-peter-thiel-mithril-20120620,0,7460860.story|title=Facebook investor Peter Thiel opens Mithril venture capital fund|date=2012-06-20|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|first=Tiffany|last=Hsu}}</ref><ref name=techcrunch-mithril>{{cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/06/19/peter-thiel-mithril/|title = Peter Thiel Launches Mithril: A New $402 Million Late-Stage Fund|last = Cutler|first = Kim-Mai|publisher = [[TechCrunch]]|date = 2012-06-19|accessdate = 2012-12-14}}</ref>
===Y Combinator=== In March 2015, it was announced that Thiel joined [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]] as one of 10 part-time partners.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.ycombinator.com/welcome-peter|title=Welcome Peter|work=Y Combinator Posthaven|accessdate=June 7, 2015}}</ref> In November 2017, it was reported that Y Combinator had severed its ties with Thiel. [[Quartz (publication)|''Quartz'']] said: "While details of the split between [Thiel] and [Y Combinator] remains unclear, the unannounced change also highlights a divergence of views. Thiel is Silicon Valley's most outspoken Trump supporter, ... YC's principals, such as president [[Sam Altman]], have made a point of calling out the threat posed by Trump."<ref>{{cite web|url =https://qz.com/1132892/peter-thiel-is-no-longer-affiliated-with-silicon-valleys-y-combinator-accelerator/|title =Peter Thiel is no longer affiliated with star accelerator Y Combinator|first =Michael J.|last =Coren|website =Quartz|date =November 17, 2017}}</ref>
==Philanthropy and donations== {{further|Thiel Foundation}}
Thiel carries out most of his philanthropic activities through a nonprofit foundation he created called the Thiel Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|title = Thiel Foundation website|url=http://www.thielfoundation.org}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.insidephilanthropy.com/guide-to-individual-donors/peter-thiel.html|title=Peter Thiel|work=Inside Philanthropy|access-date=2018-04-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Research=== ====Artificial intelligence==== In 2006, Thiel provided $100,000 of matching funds to back the Singularity Challenge donation drive of the Singularity Institute for Artificial Intelligence (now known as the [[Machine Intelligence Research Institute]]), a nonprofit organization that promotes the development of [[artificial intelligence]].<ref name=singular/> He also provided half of the $400,000 matching funds for the 2007 donation drive, and as of 2013 the Thiel Foundation has donated over $1 million to the institute.<ref name=singular>[https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/nicholas-tufnell/a-singular-sort-of-cult_b_3446089.html A Singular Sort of Cult] ''Huffington Post''</ref> Additionally, he serves on the institute's advisory board,<ref>[https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/539ajz/the-superintelligent-ai-says-youre-just-a-daydream How a Superintelligent AI Could Convince You That You're a Simulation] VICE</ref> and has spoke at multiple [[Singularity Summit]]s.<ref>[https://www.wired.com/2007/09/peter-thiel-exp/ Peter Thiel Explains How to Invest in the Singularity] Wired</ref><ref name=hplus>[http://hplusmagazine.com/2009/10/04/singularity-summit-peter-thiel-his-single-greatest-fear/ Singularity Summit – Peter Thiel On His Single Greatest Fear] H+ Magazine</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/back-to-the-future-peter-thiel-on-technology-and-investment-strategy-at-the-nyc-singularity-summit-2011-10|title=Back to the Future: Peter Thiel on Technology and Investment Strategy at the NYC Singularity Summit|publisher=}}</ref> At the 2009 Singularity Summit, he said his greatest concern is the [[technological singularity]] not arriving soon enough.<ref name=hplus/>
In December 2015, it was announced that Thiel was one of the financial backers of [[OpenAI]], a nonprofit company aimed at the safe development of [[artificial general intelligence]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/theopriestley/2015/12/11/elon-musk-and-peter-thiel-launch-openai-a-non-profit-artificial-intelligence-research-company/ |title=Elon Musk And Peter Thiel Launch OpenAI, A Non-Profit Artificial Intelligence Research Company |first1=Theo |last1=Priestly |date=December 11, 2015 |publisher=''[[Forbes]]'' |access-date=December 11, 2015 }}</ref>
====Life extension==== In September 2006, Thiel announced that he would donate $3.5 million to foster [[anti-aging]] research through the nonprofit [[Methuselah Mouse Prize]] foundation.<ref>{{cite web |title = The Mprize-PayPal Founder pledges $3.5 Million to antiaging research |accessdate = 2008-01-24 |url = http://www.mprize.org/index.php?pagename=newsdetaildisplay&ID=0107 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5aLaLUBuY?url=http://www.mprize.org/index.php?pagename=newsdetaildisplay |archivedate = August 25, 2008 |deadurl = yes |df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url =https://www.sfgate.com/health/article/BAY-AREA-Entrepreneur-backs-research-on-2469507.php|title =Entrepreneur backs research on anti-aging|website =SFGate|first =Keay|last =Davidson|date =September 18, 2006}}</ref> He gave the following reasons for his pledge: "Rapid advances in biological science foretell of a treasure trove of discoveries this century, including dramatically improved health and longevity for all. I'm backing [[Aubrey de Grey|Dr. [Aubrey] de Grey]], because I believe that his revolutionary approach to aging research will accelerate this process, allowing many people alive today to enjoy radically longer and healthier lives for themselves and their loved ones." As of February 2017, he has donated over $7 million to the foundation.<ref>[http://time.com/4672962/silicon-valley-longer-life/ How Silicon Valley Is Trying to Hack Its Way Into a Longer Life] ''Time''</ref>
When asked "What is the biggest achievement that you haven't achieved yet?" by the moderator of a discussion panel at the Venture Alpha West 2014 conference, Thiel said he wants to make progress on anti-aging research.<ref name=Reilly2014>{{cite news|last1=Reilly|first1=Richard Byrne|title=Billionaire Peter Thiel embarks on anti-aging crusade|url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/10/08/billionaire-peter-thiel-may-want-to-live-forever/|accessdate=October 22, 2014|work=Venture Beat|date=October 8, 2014}}</ref> Thiel also said that he is registered to be [[cryopreservation|cryonically preserved]], meaning that he would be subject to low-temperature preservation in case of his legal death in hopes that he might be successfully revived by future medical technology, and is signed up with the [[Alcor Life Extension Foundation]].<ref name=Brown2014/>
====Seasteading==== On April 15, 2008, Thiel pledged $500,000 to the newly-created nonprofit [[Seasteading Institute]],<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/13/business/dealbook/seasteading-floating-cities.html Floating Cities, No Longer Science Fiction, Begin to Take Shape] ''The New York Times''</ref> directed by [[Patri Friedman]], whose mission is "to establish permanent, autonomous ocean communities to enable experimentation and innovation with diverse social, political, and legal systems."<ref name=tsi20080415>{{cite web |title = Introducing The Seasteading Institute |accessdate = 2008-04-16 |url = http://seasteading.org/stay-in-touch/press-releases/introducing-the-seasteading-institute |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5aLaQdMrS?url=http://seasteading.org/stay-in-touch/press-releases/introducing-the-seasteading-institute |archivedate = August 25, 2008 |deadurl = yes |df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url =http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20160920-how-utopia-shaped-the-world|title =How Utopia shaped the world|publisher =BBC News|first =Tom|last =Hodgkinson|date =October 6, 2016}}</ref> At one of the institute's conferences, he described [[seasteading]] as "one of the few technological frontiers that has the promise to create a new space for human freedom."<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-30/floating-island-project-pushes-on-without-peter-thiel-s-support Floating Island Project Pushes On, Without Peter Thiel’s Support] Bloomberg</ref> In 2011, Thiel gave $1.25 million to the Seasteading Institute,<ref>[http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/The-312/August-2011/Milton-Friedmans-Grandson-to-Built-Floating-Libertarian-Nation/ Milton Friedman’s Grandson to Build Floating Libertarian Nation] ''Chicago''</ref><ref>[https://www.inverse.com/article/25166-peter-thiel-strangest-projects Peter Thiel's Strangest Projects] ''Inverse''</ref> but resigned from its board the same year.<ref>[https://www.businessinsider.com/libertarian-peter-thiel-utopia-seasteading-institute-2018-3 A Silicon Valley billionaire's dream of a floating libertarian utopia may have finally been killed] Business Insider</ref> In a 2017 interview with ''The New York Times'', Thiel said seasteads are "not quite feasible from an engineering perspective" and "still very far in the future".<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/11/fashion/peter-thiel-donald-trump-silicon-valley-technology-gawker.html Peter Thiel, Trump’s Tech Pal, Explains Himself] ''The New York Times''</ref><ref>[https://www.businessinsider.com/peter-thiel-seastead-dream-floating-city-2017-1 Tech billionaire Peter Thiel no longer thinks his dream of a floating libertarian utopia is realistic] ''Business Insider''</ref>
===Thiel Fellowship=== On September 29, 2010, Thiel created the [[Thiel Fellowship]], which annually awards $100,000 to 20 people under the age of 20 in order to spur them to drop out of college and create their own ventures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://20under20.org |title=The Thiel Fellowship |publisher=20 Under 20 |date=2010-09-29 |accessdate=2010-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title = Peter Thiel Launches Fellowship Program| accessdate = 2010-09-30| url = http://www.silicontap.com/peter_thiel_launches_fellowship_program/s-0031372.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/no-headline-available-1387303362|title =Why a Nonprofit Backs Dropping Out of School|first =Lora|last =Kolodny|website =The Wall Street Journal|date =December 18, 2013}}</ref> According to Thiel, for many young people, college is the path to take when they have no idea what to do with their lives:
{{quote|I feel I was personally very guilty of this; you don't know what to do with your life, so you get a college degree; you don't know what you're going to do with your college degree, so you get a graduate degree. In my case it was law school, which is the classic thing one does when one has no idea what else to do. I don't have any big regrets, but if I had to do it over I would try to think more about the future than I did at the time... You cannot get out of student debt even if you personally go bankrupt, it's a form of almost like indentured servitude, it's attached to your physical person for the rest of your life.<ref name=Brown2014/>}}
===Breakout Labs=== In November 2011, the Thiel Foundation announced the creation of [[Breakout Labs]], a grant-making program intended to "to fill the funding gap that exists for innovative research outside the confines of an academic institution, large corporation, or government."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.breakoutlabs.org/about-us.html |title=Breakout Labs about page |publisher=Breakoutlabs.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114103546/http://www.breakoutlabs.org/about-us.html |archivedate=November 14, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=naturebl>[http://blogs.nature.com/news/2012/04/paypal-co-founders-breakout-labs-issues-first-grants.html PayPal co-founder’s Breakout Labs issues first grants] Nature</ref> It offers grants of up to $350,000 to science-focused startups, "with no strings attached".<ref name=forbesbl>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/ryanmac/2013/04/17/peter-thiels-breakout-labs-turns-more-science-projects-into-businesses/#44b6c1f21d2f Peter Thiel's Breakout Labs Turns More Science Projects Into Businesses] Forbes</ref><ref name=techcrunchbl>[https://techcrunch.com/2017/09/14/breakout-ventures-spun-out-of-peter-thiels-breakout-labs-has-closed-its-debut-fund-with-60m/ Breakout Ventures, spun out of Peter Thiel’s Breakout Labs, has closed its debut fund with $60M] TechCrunch</ref> In April 2012, Breakout Labs announced its first set of grantees.<ref name=naturebl/><ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.breakoutlabs.org/news-events/news-event-item/article/breakout-labs-announces-first-grantees.html| title = Breakout Labs press release on first batch of grantees| accessdate = 2012-06-08| date = 2012-04-17| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120616114659/https://www.breakoutlabs.org/news-events/news-event-item/article/breakout-labs-announces-first-grantees.html| archivedate = June 16, 2012| df = mdy-all}}</ref> In total, 12 startups received funding, for a total of $4.5 million in grants.<ref name=forbesbl/> One of the first ventures to receive funding from Breakout Labs was [[3Scan]], a [[Automated tissue image analysis|tissue imaging]] platform.<ref name=techcrunchbl/>
===Other causes=== The Thiel Foundation is a supporter of the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] (CPJ), which promotes the right of journalists to report the news freely without fear of reprisal.<ref>{{cite web|author=Supporters of Press Freedom |url=http://www.cpj.org/about/current-supporters.php |title=Supporters of Press Freedom – About CPJ – Committee to Protect Journalists |publisher=Cpj.org |date= |accessdate=2010-10-16}}</ref> Beginning in 2008, Thiel has donated over $1 million to the CPJ.<ref>{{cite book|title =Conspiracy: Peter Thiel, Hulk Hogan, Gawker, and the Anatomy of Intrigue|first =Ryan|last =Holiday|publisher =Penguin Books|date =2018|isbn =9780735217669|page =45}}</ref> He is also a supporter of the [[Human Rights Foundation]], which organizes the [[Oslo Freedom Forum]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://thielfoundation.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1&Itemid=8|accessdate = 2012-06-08|title = Freedom Project page on Thiel Foundation website|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120525072242/http://thielfoundation.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1&Itemid=8|archivedate = May 25, 2012|df = mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=thestreet/> In 2011 he was a featured speaker at the Oslo Freedom Forum, and the Thiel Foundation was one of the event's main sponsors.<ref name=thestreet>[https://www.thestreet.com/story/11154811/1/peter-thiel-urges-investing-in-human-rights.html Peter Thiel Urges Investing in Human Rights] TheStreet</ref>
In 2011, Thiel made a [[New Zealand dollar|NZ$]]1 million donation to an appeal fund for the casualties of the [[2011 Christchurch earthquake|Christchurch earthquake]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/88746174/billionaire-donald-trump-supporter-peter-thiel-sending-more-of-his-mates-our-way|title=Billionaire Donald Trump supporter Peter Thiel sending more of his mates our way|first1=Martin|last=van Beynen|first2=Dasha|last2=Kuprienko|website=Stuff.co.nz|date=January 25, 2017}}</ref>
==Political activities== Thiel is a member of the Steering Committee of the [[Bilderberg Group]], a private, annual gathering of intellectual figures, political leaders and business executives.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cadwalladr|first1=Carole|title=Peter Thiel: 'We attribute too much to luck. Luck is an atheistic word for God'|accessdate=September 21, 2014|work=[[The Observer]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/sep/21/peter-thiel-paypal-luck-atheist-god|date=September 21, 2014|page=8}}</ref>
===Support for political activism=== Thiel, who himself is gay,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-10-07/peter-thiel-criticizes-harvard-business-school-praises-aspergers|title=Peter Thiel on Creativity: Asperger's Promotes It, Business School Crushes It|newspaper=[[Bloomberg Businessweek|BusinessWeek]]|date=October 7, 2014|last=Kitroeff|first=Natalie}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/12/23/us/gender-gaps-stanford-94.html?_r=0|title=For Stanford Class of '94, a Gender Gap More Powerful Than the Internet|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=December 23, 2014|last=Kantor|first=Jodi|authorlink=Jodi Kantor}}</ref> has supported gay rights causes such as the [[American Foundation for Equal Rights]] and [[GOProud]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Weisberg|first=Jacob|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2010/10/turn_on_start_up_drop_out.html|title=Hyper-libertarian Facebook billionaire Peter Thiel's appalling plan to pay students to quit college|website=Slate|date=October 16, 2010}}</ref> He invited conservative columnist [[Ann Coulter]], who is a friend of his, to Homocon 2010 as a guest speaker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2013/04/13/coulter-norquist-spar-over-immigration-reform/ |title=Coulter, Norquist spar over immigration reform |work =The Daily Caller |date= April 13, 2013|accessdate=December 25, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rushlimbaugh.com/daily/2011/05/25/maybe_going_to_college_really_isn_t_the_next_thing_you_should_do |title=Maybe Going to College Really Isn't the Next Thing You Should Do |publisher=The Rush Limbaugh Show |date= May 25, 2011|accessdate=December 25, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/fashion/10coulter.html?pagewanted=all |title=Outflanked on Right, Coulter Seeks New Image |work =The New York Times |date= October 8, 2010|accessdate=December 25, 2013}}</ref> Coulter later dedicated her 2011 book, ''[[Demonic: How the Liberal Mob Is Endangering America]]'', to Thiel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.librarything.com/work/11297673 |title=Demonic: How the Liberal Mob Is Endangering America |publisher=Library Thing |date= |accessdate=December 25, 2013}}</ref> Thiel is also mentioned in the acknowledgments of Coulter's ''[[¡Adios, America!: The Left's Plan to Turn Our Country Into a Third World Hellhole]]''.<ref name="coulter280">{{cite book|last1=Coulter|first1=Ann|title=¡Adios, America! : The Left's Plan to Turn Our Country into a Third World Hell Hole|date=2015|publisher=Regnery Publishing|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=9781621576068|oclc=949987257|page=280|quote=Others who have helped with this book, mostly by reading chapters and voting on titles, but in other ways, as well, are: Bill Armistead, Jon Caldara, Peter Brimelow, Rodney Conover, Mallory and Thomas Danaher, David Friedman, James Fulford, Ron Gordon, Kevin Harrington, David Limbaugh, Jay Mann, Jim Moody, Dan Travers, Jon Tukel, Marshall Sella, Peter Thiel, Kelly Victory, and Younis Zubchevich.}}</ref> In 2012, Thiel donated $10,000 to Minnesotans United for All Families, in order to fight [[Minnesota Amendment 1]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.minnpost.com/data/2012/11/who-funding-marriage-amendment-fight |title=Who is funding the marriage amendment fight? |work =Minn Post |date= November 1, 2012 |accessdate=December 25, 2013}}</ref>
In 2009, it was reported that Thiel helped fund college student [[James O'Keefe]]'s "Taxpayers Clearing House" video – a satirical look at the [[Wall Street bailout]].<ref name = Thrasher>{{cite news |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/news/conservative-facebook-investor-funded-anti-acorn-videographer-6687024 |work=[[Village Voice]] |title=The Money Trail – Conservative Facebook Investor Funded Anti-ACORN Videographer |author=[[Steven Thrasher]] |date=September 22, 2009}}</ref> O'Keefe went on to produce the [[ACORN 2009 undercover videos controversy|ACORN undercover sting videos]] but, through a spokesperson, Thiel denied involvement in the ACORN sting.<ref name = Thrasher/>
In July 2012, Thiel made a $1 million donation to the [[Club for Growth]], a fiscally conservative [[501(c)(4) organization]], becoming the group's largest contributor.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://go.bloomberg.com/political-capital/2012-08-20/thiels-1-million-tops-donors-to-club-for-growth-super-pac/ |title=Thiel's $1 Million Tops Donors to Club for Growth Super-PAC| publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | author=Gregory Giroux|date=August 20, 2012}}</ref>
===Support for political candidates=== An ideological [[libertarianism|libertarian]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politicslaw.org/peter-thiel-technology-globalization-economy/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130506063307/http://www.politicslaw.org/peter-thiel-technology-globalization-economy/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=May 6, 2013|title=Peter Thiel on the Role of Technology and Globalization in Our Economy|work=Politics Law & Economics Blog|first=Aaron|last=Street|date=March 2, 2013|accessdate=2013-12-25}}</ref> Thiel is a lifelong member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]].<ref name=DW/> He contributes to [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] and Republican candidates and causes.
In December 2007, Thiel endorsed [[Ron Paul]] for [[Ron Paul presidential campaign, 2008|President]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Endorsements » Blog Archive » Peter Thiel |accessdate=2008-01-24 |url=http://people.ronpaul2008.com/endorsements/2007/12/22/peter-thiel/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123224151/http://people.ronpaul2008.com/endorsements/2007/12/22/peter-thiel/ |archivedate=January 23, 2008 }}</ref> After Paul failed to secure the Republican nomination, Thiel contributed to the [[John McCain]] [[John McCain presidential campaign, 2008|campaign]].<ref name="Political Campaign Contributions" />
In 2010, Thiel supported [[Meg Whitman]] in her unsuccessful bid for the [[California gubernatorial election, 2010|governorship of California]]. He contributed the maximum allowable $25,900 to the Whitman campaign.<ref>Fost, Dan, [https://blogs.forbes.com/danfost/2010/09/17/old-paypals-peter-thiel-backs-meg-whitman/ "Old (Pay)Pals: Peter Thiel backs Meg Whitman"], ''Forbes'' blog, 17 September 2010. Retrieved 2011-01-11.</ref>
[[File:Peter Thiel 2016 RNC (1) (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|Thiel speaking at the [[2016 Republican National Convention]]]] In 2012, Thiel, along with [[Luke Nosek]] and [[Scott Banister]], put their support behind the [[Endorse Liberty]] Super PAC. Collectively Thiel ''et al.'' gave $3.9 million to Endorse Liberty, whose purpose was to promote [[Ron Paul]] [[Ron Paul presidential campaign, 2012|for president in 2012]]. As of January 31, 2012, Endorse Liberty reported spending about $3.3 million promoting Paul by setting up two [[YouTube]] channels, buying ads from [[Google]], [[Facebook]] and [[StumbleUpon]], and building a presence on the Web.<ref name=Reuters>{{Cite news|last=Selyukh|first=Alina|title=PayPal co-founders fund pro-Paul Super PAC|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/31/us-usa-campaign-spending-paul-idUSTRE80U1OF20120131|accessdate=2012-01-31|newspaper=Reuters|date=2012-01-31}}</ref> At the [[2012 Republican National Convention]], Thiel held a private meeting with [[Rand Paul]] and Ron Paul's presidential delegates to discuss "the future of the Liberty Movement."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/ron-paul-rand-peter-thiel-liberty-tampa-facebook-billionaire-gop-2012-8|title=Rand Paul Is Hanging Out With Facebook Billionaire Peter Thiel At The GOP Convention|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=December 25, 2013}}</ref> After Ron Paul again failed to secure the Republican nomination for president, Thiel contributed to the [[Mitt Romney]]/[[Paul Ryan]] [[Mitt Romney presidential campaign, 2012|presidential ticket of 2012]].<ref name="Political Campaign Contributions" />
Thiel initially supported [[Carly Fiorina]] campaign during the 2016 GOP presidential primary elections.<ref name=ABC>{{Cite news|last=Kim|first=Susanna|title=Billionaire Paypal Co-Founder Peter Thiel on List of Trump Backers|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/billionaire-paypal-founder-peter-thiel-list-trump-backers/story?id=39006891|accessdate=2016-05-10|newspaper=ABC News|date=2016-05-10}}</ref> After Fiorina dropped out, Thiel supported [[Donald Trump]] and became one of the pledged California delegates for Trump's nomination at the [[2016 Republican National Convention]]. He was also a headline speaker during the convention, during which he announced that he was "proud to be gay".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Selyukh|first1=Alina|title='I Am Proud To Be Gay,' Tech Investor Peter Thiel Tells GOP Convention|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/07/21/486966882/i-am-proud-to-be-gay-tech-investor-peter-thiel-tells-gop-convention|website=NPR|accessdate=July 22, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Margolin |first=Emma |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/openly-gay-libertarian-tech-entrepreneur-peter-thiel-speak-rnc-n614191 |title=Peter Thiel Makes History at RNC: 'I'm Proud to be Gay' |publisher=NBC News |date=2016 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref> On October 15, 2016, Thiel announced a $1.25 million donation in support of [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump's presidential campaign]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Streitfeld|first1=David|title=Peter Thiel to Donate $1.25 Million in Support of Donald Trump|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/16/technology/peter-thiel-donald-j-trump.html|accessdate=October 16, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=October 15, 2016}}</ref> Thiel stated to ''The New York Times'': "I didn't give him any money for a long time because I didn't think it mattered, and then the campaign asked me to."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/11/fashion/peter-thiel-donald-trump-silicon-valley-technology-gawker.html|title=Peter Thiel, Trump's Tech Pal, Explains Himself|first=Maureen|last=Dowd|website=The New York Times|date=January 11, 2017}}</ref> After Trump's victory, Thiel was named to the executive committee of the President-elect's [[Presidential transition of Donald Trump#Transition team|transition team]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/11/11/thiel-trump-transition-team/|title=Silicon Valley Investor Peter Thiel Will Join Trump's Transition Team|first=Kia|last=Kokalitcheva|website=Fortune|date=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
Other politicians Thiel has contributed donations to include:<ref name="Political Campaign Contributions">Peter Thiel Political Campaign Contributions (CampaignMoney.com) * {{Cite news|title=Peter Thiel Political Campaign Contributions 2000 Election Cycle|url=http://www.campaignmoney.com/political/contributions/peter-thiel.asp?cycle=00}} * {{Cite news|title=Peter Thiel Political Campaign Contributions 2002 Election Cycle|url=http://www.campaignmoney.com/political/contributions/peter-thiel.asp?cycle=02}} * {{Cite news|title=Peter Thiel Political Campaign Contributions 2004 Election Cycle|url=http://www.campaignmoney.com/political/contributions/peter-thiel.asp?cycle=04}} * {{Cite news|title=Peter Thiel Political Campaign Contributions 2006 Election Cycle|url=http://www.campaignmoney.com/political/contributions/peter-thiel.asp?cycle=06}} * {{Cite news|title=Peter Thiel Political Campaign Contributions 2008 Election Cycle|url=http://www.campaignmoney.com/political/contributions/peter-thiel.asp?cycle=08}} * {{Cite news|title=Peter Thiel Political Campaign Contributions 2010 Election Cycle|url=http://www.campaignmoney.com/political/contributions/peter-thiel.asp?cycle=10}} * {{Cite news|title=Peter Thiel Political Campaign Contributions 2012 Election Cycle|url=http://www.campaignmoney.com/political/contributions/peter-thiel.asp?cycle=12}} * {{Cite news|title=Peter Thiel Political Campaign Contributions 2014 Election Cycle|url=http://www.campaignmoney.com/political/contributions/peter-thiel.asp?cycle=14}}</ref> {{Div col|colwidth=16em}} * Sen. [[Lamar Alexander]] * [[Randy Altschuler]] * Rep. [[Justin Amash]] * Rep. [[Roscoe Bartlett]] * Rep. [[Bob Beauprez]] * Rep. [[Mary Bono]] * [[Ryan Brumberg]] * Rep. [[Eric Cantor]] * Rep.
