Removing link(s) to "GameZone": Article deleted per [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/GameZone]]. | [[WP:TW|TW]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:Twitch Plays ''Pokémon''}} [[File:Twitch plays pokemon animated.gif|thumb|Commands identified by the [[game engine]] shown on-screen (right of image) are applied to the [[player character]] in ''[[Pokémon Red]]'' (left)]] '''Twitch Plays ''Pokémon''''' ('''TPP''') is a [[social experiment]] and channel on the [[video game live streaming]] website [[Twitch (website)|Twitch]], consisting of a [[crowdsourcing|crowdsourced]] attempt to play [[Game Freak]]'s and [[Nintendo]]'s [[Pokémon (video game series)|''Pokémon'' video games]] by parsing commands sent by users through the channel's [[chat room]]. It holds the ''[[Guinness World Record]]'' for having "the most participants on a single-player online videogame" with 1,165,140.<ref name=record/>
The concept was developed by an anonymous Australian programmer and launched on 12 February 2014, starting with the game ''[[Pokémon Red]]''. The stream became unexpectedly popular, reaching an average concurrent viewership of over 80,000 viewers (with at least 10% participating). On 1 March 2014, the game was completed after more than 16 continuous days of gameplay; Twitch estimated that over 1.16 million people participated, with peak simultaneous participation at 121,000, and with a total of 55 million views during the experiment.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://blog.twitch.tv/2014/03/twitch-prevails-at-pokemon/ | title = Victory! The Thundershock Heard Around the World | author = Chase | publisher = [[Twitch (website)|Twitch]] | date = 1 March 2014 | accessdate= 1 March 2014 }}</ref> On 5 December 2014, Twitch Plays ''Pokémon'' received a [[The Game Awards|Game Award]] in the "Best Fan Creation" category.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thegameawards.com/nominees/ |title=The Game Awards Nominees 2014 |accessdate=7 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151114024126/http://thegameawards.com/nominees/ |archivedate=14 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The experiment was met with attention by media outlets and staff members of Twitch for its interactivity, its erratic and chaotic nature, the unique challenges faced by players due to the mechanics of its system, and the community and [[Internet meme|memes]] developed by participants. Following the completion of ''Red'', the broadcaster continued the channel with many other games in the ''Pokémon'' series along with unofficial [[ROM hacking|ROM hacks]]. The broadcaster has plans to continue with other ''Pokémon'' games as long as there remains interest in the channel. The success of the experiment led to a number of similar Twitch-based streams for other games, and led Twitch to promote more streams with similar interactivity with watchers.
== Premise == Inspired by another Twitch-based interactive game, ''Salty Bet'' (a website where users could wager on the outcome of randomized ''[[M.U.G.E.N.]]'' matches)<ref name="ars-tpp">{{cite web | url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2014/02/the-bizarre-mind-numbing-mesmerizing-beauty-of-twitch-plays-pokemon/ | title=The bizarre, mind-numbing, mesmerizing beauty of "Twitch Plays Pokémon" | publisher=Condé Nast Publications | work=Ars Technica | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref> and described as a [[social experiment]], the system used by the stream was coded by an anonymous Australian programmer, colloquially known as the "Streamer", consisting of an [[IRC bot]] written in [[Python (programming language)|Python]] and the [[Game Boy]] [[Video game emulator|emulator]] [[VisualBoyAdvance]]. The script captures specific messages (directional commands, "B", "A", "select", and "start") sent into the stream's chat room by users, and sends them to the emulator as button input, thus controlling the game. An additional web app coded using [[JavaScript]] is used to display a live tally of moves that are shown within the stream. The Streamer chose ''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'' for the project, citing nostalgia for the early games,<ref name=cnet-theydidit/> the fact that "Even when played very poorly it is difficult not to make progress in ''Pokémon''",<ref name="beat">{{cite web | url=http://www.joystiq.com/2014/02/20/twitch-plays-pokemon-but-can-twitch-beat-pokemon/ | title=Twitch Plays Pokemon, but can Twitch beat Pokemon? | publisher=AOL | work=Joystiq | date=20 February 2014 | accessdate=25 March 2014 | author=Xav de Matos}}</ref> and because its current control structure "[wouldn't] work with any genre that isn't a [[History of Eastern role-playing video games#Japanese computer RPGs|JRPG]]", particularly targeting its "forgiving" turn-based structure and lack of reaction-based gameplay, compensating for the large amount of [[input lag]] between the game and the stream. The Streamer used an [[ROM hacking|edited]] version of the game, which claims to make all the original 151 Pokémon accessible, in hopes of making completion of the [[Pokédex]] a possibility. However, the edited version used was unfinished and has no gameplay differences when compared to the original game.<ref name=cnet-theydidit/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://business.financialpost.com/2014/02/19/twitch-plays-pokemon-a-wild-experiment-in-crowd-sourced-gameplay/?__lsa=e52a-6474 | title=Twitch Plays Pokémon a wild experiment in crowd sourced gameplay | publisher=[[Postmedia Network]] | work=Financial Post | last=O'Mara | first=Matthew}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=M0D3Rn|title=An interview with the creator of TwitchPlaysPokémon!|url=http://badatvideogames.net/2014/02/16/an-interview-with-the-creator-of-twitchplayspokemon/|work=BADatVIDEOGAMES|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228233606/http://badatvideogames.net/2014/02/16/an-interview-with-the-creator-of-twitchplayspokemon/|archivedate=28 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="gs-tpp80k">{{cite web | url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/over-60k-people-watching-twitch-play-pokemon-update/1100-6417762/ | title=Over 60k people watching Twitch play Pokémon [UPDATE] | publisher=CBS Interactive | work=GameSpot | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref><ref name="polygon-tpp">{{cite web | url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/2/14/5411790/twitch-plays-pokemon-creator-interview-twitchplayspokemon | title=How Twitch is crowd-sourcing an amazing Pokémon multiplayer game | publisher=Vox Media | work=Polygon | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=polygon-65million/>
The erratic nature of the control scheme has made the game longer and harder to play than under normal circumstances; an ''[[Ars Technica]]'' writer commented that "([[Red (Pokémon)#Player characters|Red]]) gets stuck in corners. He walks in circles, compulsively checking his Pokédex and saving over and over again. Commands stream in from the chat channel faster than the game can possibly process them, making progress difficult-to-impossible even without the lag factor or the 'help' of gleeful trolls." Recurring difficulties have occurred with areas of the game involving mazes and ledges (areas with the latter taking as long as several hours to navigate due to users intentionally sending "down" commands to jump off the ledges), the accidental release of several Pokémon (including an incident referred to as "Bloody Sunday," where a total of twelve Pokémon were accidentally released whilst trying to manipulate the character's party),<ref name="gz-bloodysunday">{{cite web | url=http://www.gamezone.com/originals/2014/02/25/bloody-sunday-in-kanto-this-weekend-in-twitch-plays-pokemon | title=Bloody Sunday in Kanto—This weekend in Twitch Plays Pokemon | publisher=GameZone Online | work=GameZone | accessdate=1 March 2014}}</ref> and users repeatedly sending "start" commands to open the pause menu, often followed by opening the character's inventory to select random items.<ref name=ars-tpp/><ref name="kotaku-miraculous">{{cite web | url=http://kotaku.com/the-miraculous-progress-of-twitch-plays-pokemon-1524605696 | title=The Miraculous Progress of 'Twitch Plays Pokémon' | publisher=Gawker Media | work=Kotaku | accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=independent-tpp>{{cite web|title=Twitch Plays Pokémon is 'like watching a car crash in slow motion'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/twitch-plays-pokmon-the-largest-massively-multiplayer-pokmon-game-is-beautiful-chaos-9133732.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref> A system to throttle inputs on the Start button was added to mitigate this particular effect.<ref name=polygon-beatable/>
Despite the seemingly erratic process of playing the game, players have attempted to collaborate and strategize through various means, including infographics and a [[user script]] which hides command messages from the chat window to allow conversation. This was necessary for the players to progress as several areas of the game require coordinated actions to gain Pokémon with a specific skill needed to clear obstacles in Red's way, and earlier attempts without such coordination resulted in missing out on specific opportunities early on in the playthrough. In essence, the majority of players have attempted to counteract [[Internet troll|trolls]] trying to impede progress.<ref name=ars-tpp/><ref name=kotaku-miraculous/><ref name="kotaku-progress">{{cite web | url=http://kotaku.com/how-people-are-actually-making-progress-in-twitch-play-1525261786 | title=How Players Actually Make Progress in 'Twitch Plays Pokémon' | publisher=Gawker Media | work=Kotaku | accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> A computer program was even created to automatically identify these trolls.<ref name="HAQUE2014">A. Haque. "[http://albert.cm/dl/twitch_paper.pdf Unsupervised Context-Aware Anomaly Detection for Identifying Trolls in Streaming Data]," ''Department of Computer Science, University of Texas at Austin'', 2014.</ref>
The Streamer has since collaborated with others to continue preparing tools for the games for the Twitch channel. This group had added live commentary on the games as they were played. As a result of intra-group hostility from some of the collaborates, the Streamer will step down from his role as lead for Twitch Plays Pokemon on November 22, 2017, and give control to another collaborator.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://kotaku.com/twitch-plays-pokemon-s-creator-says-he-is-stepping-down-1820486151 | title = Twitch Plays Pokémon’s Creator Says He Is Stepping Down Following Alleged Doxing | first = Gita | last = Jackson | date = November 15, 2017 | accessdate = November 15, 2017 | work = [[Kotaku]] }}</ref>
== Progression and further games == On 18 February 2014, after encountering major difficulties with a puzzle in the [[Team Rocket]] hideout, a new mechanic was introduced in an effort to make the game easier to play. Initially, all movements became subject to a vote: all inputs received over a period of time (usually 30 seconds) were tallied, and the winning command would be executed at the end of that time. Users could also append their movements with numbers to specify the length of the motion, such as "right3" to mean three consecutive "right" inputs. Many people were outraged over this new system and protest broke out in the Twitch chat, many of them using the command "start9" (which would open and close the pause menu nine times to slow down progress) to fight the system. The broadcaster later reworked the mechanic so that users could vote to switch between two modes: "Anarchy", the previous default, and this new mode "Democracy."<ref name=nouse>{{cite web | url=http://www.nouse.co.uk/2014/02/27/twitch-plays-pokemon/| title=Twitch Plays Pokémon | author=Niall Whitehead | date=27 February 2014 | publisher=Nouse }}</ref><ref name=soul>{{cite web | title='Twitch Plays Pokemon' is now a fight for the soul of the Internet | url=http://www.cnet.com/news/twitch-plays-pokemon-is-now-a-fight-for-the-soul-of-the-internet/ | author=Nick Statt | date=21 February 2014 | publisher=CBS Interactive |work=CNET | accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref> However, a change to Democracy mode requires a [[supermajority]] vote, while a change to Anarchy mode requires only a majority vote, as indicated by an on-screen meter. This change was considered divisive by players, who believed that Democracy mode conflicted with the original concept of the stream and eliminated the potential for randomness which had helped to drive the elaborate narrative and mythology that had built up around the playthrough.<ref name=ars-tpp/><ref name="cnet-theydidit">{{cite web | url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1023_3-57619740-93/twitch-plays-pokemon-conquers-elite-four-beating-game-after-390-hours/ | title=Twitch Plays Pokemon conquers Elite Four, beating game after 390 hours | publisher=CBS Interactive | work=CNET | accessdate=1 March 2014}}</ref><ref name="polygon-beatable">{{cite web | url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/2/20/5428398/twitch-plays-pokemon-democracy-vs-anarchy | title=Twitch Plays Pokémon creator tweaks channel to make game more 'beatable' | publisher=Vox Media | work=Polygon | accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=soul/><ref name=joystiq-democracy/><ref name="mashable-religion">{{cite web | url=http://mashable.com/2014/02/19/pokemon-stream-twitch/ | title=How a Week-Long Game of Pokémon Became a War of Religion | work=[[Mashable]] | accessdate=26 February 2014}}</ref>
Following the completion of ''Pokémon Red'', a new game began on 2 March 2014, this time with the second generation game ''Pokémon Crystal''.<ref name="gs-crystal">{{cite web | url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/twitch-plays-pokemon-crystal-after-beating-pokemon-red/1100-6418045/ | title=Twitch Plays Pokemon Crystal after beating Pokemon Red | publisher=CBS Interactive | work=GameSpot | accessdate=2 March 2014}}</ref> The developer set a deadline for the completion of ''Crystal'' with the plan to start ''[[Pokémon Emerald]]'' on a fixed date, though the players were able to complete ''Crystal'' well before this point.<ref name="polygon continue">{{cite web | url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/3/25/5506594/twitch-plays-pokemon | title=Twitch Plays Pokemon will continue as long as it has an active following | publisher=Vox Media | work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] | date=25 March 2014 | accessdate=25 March 2014 | last=Farokhmanesh | first=Megan}}</ref> With the change to ''Crystal'' also came a change to the voting system; the Democracy mode was automatically activated at the top of each hour.<ref name="ign-crystal">{{cite web | url=http://ca.ign.com/articles/2014/03/03/twitch-plays-pokemon-starts-pokemon-crystal | title=Twitch Plays Pokemon Starts Pokemon Crystal | publisher=IGN Entertainment | work=IGN.com | accessdate=4 March 2014}}</ref> By 14 March 2014, players had reached a major battle on Mt. Silver against Red, a trainer representing the player-character from ''Red'' and ''Blue''; however, the game was also modified so that Red's team would consist of the same Pokémon that were used to beat the Elite Four in the Twitch Plays ''Pokémon'' playthrough of ''Pokémon Red'' earlier.<ref name="kotaku-redreturn">{{cite web | url=http://kotaku.com/lord-helix-makes-a-most-unexpected-return-in-twitch-pl-1543901152 | title=Lord Helix Makes A Most Unexpected Return In 'Twitch Plays Pokémon' | publisher=Gawker Media | work=Kotaku | accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> The developer stated that he intentionally changed the game data of ''Crystal'' to behave in this way, as it was Game Freak's original intent when creating the game that the player would face Red in ''Crystal'' using the Pokémon they had finished ''Red'' with.<ref name="polygon continue"/> ''Crystal'' was beaten on 15 March, with more than 13 days of playtime.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2014/03/15/twitch-plays-pok-233-mon-defeat-crystal-countdown-timer-starts-for-emerald.aspx | title = Twitch Plays Pokémon Defeats Crystal, Countdown Timer Starts For Emerald | first = Kyle | last = Hillard | date = 15 March 2014 | accessdate = 15 March 2014 | work = [[Game Informer]] }}</ref><ref name="emerald">{{cite web |url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/132889-Twitch-Plays-Pokemon-Interview-TPP-Will-Continue-on-to-Emerald |title=Twitch Plays Pokemon Interview: TPP Will Continue on to Emerald |last=Bogos |first=Steven |work=''[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]'' |date=13 March 2014 |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> The developer stated that even though fewer viewers watched ''Pokémon Crystal'' compared to ''Pokémon Red'', he will continue the stream with other ''Pokémon'' games as long as there remains interest in the experiment.<ref name="polygon continue"/><ref>{{cite web | url =https://venturebeat.com/2014/03/01/twitch-plays-pokemon-to-continue-with-second-gen-game-tomorrow-will-keep-going-as-long-as-people-care/ | title = Twitch Plays Pokémon continues with second-gen game—will keep going as long as people care | first = Jeffrey | last = Grubb | date = 1 March 2014 | accessdate = 2 March 2014 | publisher = [[VentureBeat]] }}</ref>
''Pokémon Emerald'' was started on 21 March 2014. With the shift to ''Emerald,'' the Democracy mode was initially disabled entirely.<ref name=escapist-emeraldbegin>{{cite web|title=Twitch Plays Pokemon Starts Pokemon Emerald, Plays as a Girl|url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/133159-Twitch-Plays-Pokemon-Starts-Pokemon-Emerald-Plays-as-a-Girl|work=The Escapist|accessdate=22 March 2014}}</ref> ''Emerald'' was repeatedly restarted due to its [[soft reset]] ability, but was later fixed by the broadcaster.<ref>{{cite web|last=James|first=Dean|url=http://www.justpushstart.com/2014/03/twitch-plays-pokemon-starts-anew-hoenn-region/|title=Twitch Plays Pokemon Starts Anew In The Hoenn Region|publisher=JustPushStart|date=22 March 2014|accessdate=23 March 2014}}</ref>
The shift to ''[[Pokémon X]]''—the 1st installment in the franchise for the [[Nintendo 3DS]], brought changes to the stream's setup. As there was no PC-based emulator for the 3DS at the time, the stream was conducted on actual 3DS hardware using a hardware modification known as the 3DS Streaming Console with External Control Interface (3xtDS); developed by Reddit user dekuNukem, also known as Twitch_plays_3ds (who has also designed an automated rig for "chaining" and detecting [[Shiny Pokémon|"shiny" Pokémon]]),<ref name=vox-shinyfinder>{{cite web|title=Modder creates Pokemon X and Y shiny-finding machine|url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/11/5/5069912/pokemon-x-y-shiny-pokemon-finder|website=Polygon|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref> the mod allows direct control of inputs on the device via an [[USB]]-based interface, and added the video output required for [[video capture|capturing]] the screens' content. The change to native hardware also allowed the stream to use the [[Wi-Fi]] capabilities of the device; other players of ''Pokémon X'' and ''Y'' could directly interact with the stream's player via [[Nintendo Network]] and the game's internet-enabled features, such as online battles, [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Pokémon trades|trades]], and O-Powers.<ref name=polygon-twitchxy>{{cite web|title=Twitch Plays Pokémon starting ''Pokémon X'' on July 27 thanks to modded 3DS|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/7/25/5937763/twitch-plays-pokemon-x-modded-3ds|website=Polygon|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref> Following its release, ''[[Pokémon Omega Ruby]]'' was also played in the stream.<ref name=polygon-twitchomegaruby>{{cite web|title=Twitch Plays Pokémon is returning for Omega Ruby, Alpha Sapphire|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/10/23/7047589/twitch-plays-pokemon-omega-ruby-alpha-sapphire|website=Polygon|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref>
In honour of the one-year anniversary of the original run, a new playing of ''Pokémon Red'' began in February 2015. The goal was to complete the game's main storyline and to catch all 151 Pokémon, the latter which they did in around 39 days.<ref name=kotaku-tpp2015>{{cite web|title=Twitch Plays Pokémon Faces Its Toughest Challenge Yet|url=http://pocketmonster.kotaku.com/twitch-plays-pokemon-faces-its-toughest-challenge-yet-1686145853|website=Pocket Monster (Kotaku)|publisher=Gawker Media|accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitchplayspokemon.org/ar/|website=Twitch Plays Pokémon|accessdate=9 January 2016}}</ref>
To celebrate the project's fourth anniversary, the channel started a new playthrough of both ''Pokémon Red'' and ''Pokémon Blue'' simultaneously. Players in the Twitch channel can specify which game their command is for, but otherwise commands are issues alternating between the two games, and when the game's democratic mode is on, the command voted on is used in both games.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://kotaku.com/four-years-later-twitch-is-playing-pokemon-red-and-blu-1822961614 | title = Four Years Later, Twitch Is Playing Pokémon Red and Blue At Once | first = Patricia | last = Hernandez | date = 13 February 2018 | accessdate = 13 February 2018 | work = [[Kotaku]] }}</ref>
== Viewership == {{Update|section|date=September 2014}} Launched on 12 February 2014 as a "[[proof of concept]]", the stream was relatively inactive for the first day and a half of playing.<ref name=beat/> However, the stream quickly went [[Viral video|viral]] after that, reaching a total viewership of around 175,000 by 14 February (when players managed to beat the first of eight [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Pokémon gyms|Gym leaders]]).<ref name=hive-mind>{{cite web | title=The hive mind at work: Twitch Plays Pokemon | url=http://gadgets.ndtv.com/games/features/the-hive-mind-at-work-twitch-plays-pokemon-499384 | author=Gopal Sathe | date=24 March 2014 | publisher=NDTV Convergence Limited | accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref> By 17 February, the channel had reached over 6.5 million total views. By 20 February, the channel had over 17 million total views, and was averaging concurrent viewership between 60 and 70 thousand viewers with at least 10% participating. By then, the players had managed to catch 12 different species of Pokémon, and made it past the fourth gym.<ref name=gs-tpp80k/><ref name=polygon-tpp/><ref name=polygon-65million>{{cite web|title=Twitch Plays Pokémon captivates with more than 6.5M total views|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/2/17/5420334/twitch-plays-pokemon-captivates-with-more-than-6-5m-total-views|work=Polygon|accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref> On the completion of ''Red'', the channel had reached 36 million total views, with a peak concurrent viewership of 120,000, and an estimated 658,000 had participated.<ref name="recode-anarchy">{{cite web |url=http://recode.net/2014/02/19/viral-video-nostalgia-memes-and-anarchy-collide-in-twitch-plays-pokemon/ |title=Viral Video; Nostalgia, Memes and Anarchy Collide in Twitch Plays Pokémon |first= Eric |last= Johnson |work=Re/code |accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mashable.com/2014/02/19/pokemon-stream-twitch/ |title=How a Week-Long Game of Pokémon Became a War of Religion |first= Alex |last= Magdaleno |work=[[Mashable]] |accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref> The ''Red'' stream was eventually recognized by the ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' for having "the most participants on a single-player online videogame" with 1,165,140.<ref name=record>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/records-6000/most-participants-on-a-single-player-online-videogame/|title=MOST PARTICIPANTS ON A SINGLE-PLAYER ONLINE VIDEOGAME|work=[[Guinness World Records]]|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> The large amount of activity on the stream resulted in "enormous (and unforeseen) stress" on Twitch's chat system, requiring the site's engineers to move the stream's chat to a higher-capacity server normally used during major [[e-sports]] events, while working on improving the infrastructure's [[scalability]].<ref name=twitch-recentchatissues>{{cite web|title=Recent Chat Issues and TwitchPlaysPokémon|url=http://blog.twitch.tv/2014/02/recent-chat-issues-and-twitchplayspokemon/|work=Twitch.tv Official Blog|accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> The developer himself said, "I didn't think it was going to be this popular, I thought it would gain only a small group of dedicated viewers and many others would check it out briefly before moving on to other things. It's overwhelming how popular it has become."<ref name=beat/>
==Community== [[File:Helix_Bible.jpg|thumb|right|"Bible" published by community members]] An active community of players also emerged on communities and social networks such as [[Reddit]], which have [[liveblog]]ged the proceedings and developed [[Internet meme|memes]] and other works around occurrences in the game. One item in Red's inventory from the start of the game was the Helix Fossil, which was used later in the game to revive [[Omanyte]], but is otherwise functionless. The Helix Fossil was selected so frequently that it became an [[inside joke]] among players, and at times humorously calling it a [[deity]] which the player-character was constantly consulting for advice, and it quickly became the players' "religion". Players went as far as treating the fossil as a symbol representing a [[sect]] which supports Anarchy mode, while treating its counterpart, the Dome Fossil (which revives [[Kabuto (Pokémon)|Kabuto]]), as a deity to those who support Democracy mode.<ref name=ars-tpp/><ref name=kotaku-miraculous/><ref name=mashable-religion/><ref name="recode-anarchy"/> Fans even published "bibles" for the Helix religion.<ref>Stone, Michael, [https://www.thebookpatch.com/BookStore/the-helix-bible/d9bdbd3a-52cf-44b1-9d4f-00901e9243ea The Helix Bible] </ref><ref>[https://issuu.com/audreydijeau/docs/the_book_of_helix_kanto_and_johto The Book of Helix]</ref> Certain Pokémon captured by Red during the gameplay have also gained fan followings. Two Pokémon that were obtained early in the game, and then later accidentally released were the [[Charmeleon]] and [[Rattata]], "ABBBBBBK("<!-- Yes, that parenthesis is supposed to be there. Note: There is no space between K and (; Pokémon has a monospace font; and the parenthesis hangs on the right half of the character, which creates a gap, making people believe there is a space. --> and "JLVWNNOOOO", further nicknamed "Abby" and "[[Jay Leno]]".<ref name=ars-tpp/><ref name=kotaku-miraculous/> The team's [[Pidgeot]], one of the highest level Pokémon in the group and often successful in battles, was named "Bird Jesus" by the community; concurrently, the team's [[Zapdos]] was nicknamed "AA-j" but referred to as "Archangel of Justice" or "Anarchy Bird".<ref name=ars-tpp/><ref name=kotaku-miraculous/><ref name=escapist-crystalbeaten/> Their [[Flareon]] was dubbed the "False Prophet", as players had accidentally obtained it instead of [[Vaporeon]], which was needed so they could teach it the "Surf" move needed to travel on water, and it had later caused the release of the Charmeleon and Rattata.<ref name="joystiq-recap">{{cite web | url=http://www.joystiq.com/2014/02/22/twitch-plays-pokemon-its-history-highlights-and-bird-jesus/ | title=Twitch Plays Pokemon: Its history, highlights and Bird Jesus | publisher=AOL | work=Joystiq | accessdate=1 March 2014}}</ref> During the eleventh day of the event (23 February), which fell on a Sunday, the players inadvertently released a dozen of the captured Pokémon, effectively deleting the creatures from the game, an event that later became known as "Bloody Sunday".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.avclub.com/article/praise-helix-strange-hilarious-mythology-crowdsour-202017 | title=Praise Helix: The strange mythology of a crowdsourced Pokémon game | work=[[The A.V. Club]] | date=11 March 2014 | accessdate=11 March 2014 | last=Barsanti | first=Sam}}</ref> The practice of nicknames continued into ''Crystal'', which included a new Pidgeot nicknamed "[[Monty Python's Life of Brian|Brian]]", and a [[Feraligatr]] nicknamed "Lazorgator".<ref name=escapist-crystalbeaten>{{cite web|title=Twitch Plays Pokemon Beats Pokemon Crystal|url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/132954-Twitch-Plays-Pokemon-Beats-Pokemon-Crystal|work=The Escapist|accessdate=22 March 2014}}</ref>
== Reception == Media outlets have described the proceedings of the game as being "mesmerizing," "miraculous," and "beautiful chaos," with one viewer comparing it to "watching a car crash in slow motion."<ref name=ars-tpp/><ref name=kotaku-miraculous/><ref name=independent-tpp/> [[Ars Technica]] felt that it encapsulated "the best and worst qualities of our user-driven, novelty-hungry age," providing hours of arguable time-wasting entertainment through a word-of-mouth viral distribution.<ref name=ars-tpp/> The stream has been compared to the [[infinite monkey theorem]] in that effectively random input to a game still ultimately comes out with forward progress in the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2014/02/16/twitch-plays-pokemon-wasted-our-entire-weekend-was-it-worth-it/74496/|title=Twitch Plays Pokémon Wasted Our Entire Weekend; Was It Worth It?|first=Nikola|last=Suprak|date=17 February 2014|accessdate=17 February 2014|publisher=[[Hardcore Gamer]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gamersyndrome.com/2014/news/twitch-plays-pokemon-infinite-mankey-theorem-follows-suit/|title=Twitch Plays Pokémon: Infinite Mankey Theorem Follows Suit|first=Pashford|last=Murano|date=18 February 2014|accessdate=18 February 2014|publisher=[[Gamersyndrome]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223035301/http://gamersyndrome.com/2014/news/twitch-plays-pokemon-infinite-mankey-theorem-follows-suit/|archivedate=23 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Twitch vice president of marketing Matthew DiPietro praised the stream, considering it "one more example of how video games have become a platform for entertainment and creativity that extends WAY beyond the original intent of the game creator. By merging a video game, live video and a participatory experience, the broadcaster has created an entertainment hybrid custom made for the Twitch community. This is a wonderful proof on concept that we hope to see more of in the future."<ref name=gs-tpp80k/>
== Legacy == ''Twitch Plays Pokémon'' has also inspired imitators with other video games, such as ''Pokémon Blue'', ''[[QWOP]]'', ''[[Tetris]]'' (including one which used the actual command inputs from the original Twitch Plays ''Pokémon'' stream),<ref name=beat/><ref name="kotaku-tetris">{{cite web | url=http://kotaku.com/thousands-of-people-are-playing-tetris-without-realizin-1525521488 | title=Thousands of People Are Playing Tetris Without Realizing It | publisher=Gawker Media | work=Kotaku | accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref> ''[[Street Fighter II]]'',<ref name=gs-tpp80k/><ref name=polygon-tpp/><ref name=kotaku-miraculous/><ref name="joystiq-democracy">{{cite web | url=http://www.joystiq.com/2014/02/18/twitch-plays-pokemon-levels-up-to-75k-concurrent-viewers-learns/ | title=Twitch Plays Pokémon levels up to 75k concurrent viewers, learns democracy | publisher=AOL | work=Joystiq | accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref><ref name="kotaku-helixfossilrevive">{{cite web | url=http://kotaku.com/rejoice-for-twitch-plays-pokemon-has-revived-the-hel-1529832673 | title=Rejoice, For 'Twitch Plays Pokémon' Has Revived The Helix Fossil | publisher=Gawker Media | work=Kotaku | accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> ''[[Halo: Combat Evolved]]'' (itself made significantly difficult by its nature as a [[first-person shooter]]),<ref name=polygon-twitchhalo>{{cite web|last1=Gera|first1=Emily|title=Twitch is playing Halo and it is so painful to watch|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/2/27/8119189/twitch-plays-halo|website=Polygon|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=1 March 2015}}</ref> ''[[Metal Gear: Ghost Babel]]'',<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://kotaku.com/twitch-is-playing-metal-gear-its-not-going-well-1716112711 | title = Twitch Is Playing Metal Gear. It's Not Going Well | date = 6 July 2015 | accessdate = 14 August 2015 | first = Luke | last = Plunkett | publisher = [[Kotaku]] }}</ref> ''[[Dark Souls]]'',<ref>{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2015/08/twitch-has-gone-crazy-and-is-trying-to-play-dark-souls/ | title = Twitch has gone crazy and is trying to play Dark Souls | publisher = [[Ars Technica]] | date = 14 August 2015 | accessdate = 14 August 2015 | first = Mark | last = Walton }}</ref> ''[[Fallout 3]]'',<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pcgamer.com/twitch-plays-fallout-3-looks-tough-but-will-probably-be-won/ | title = Twitch Plays Fallout 3 looks tough, but will probably be won | publisher = [[PC Gamer]] | date = 20 September 2015 | accessdate = 30 September 2015 | first = Shaun | last = Prescott }}</ref> ''[[PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds]]'',<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pcgamer.com/twitch-plays-pubg-and-has-already-managed-to-finish-third-place-in-a-game/ | title = Twitch Plays PUBG and has already managed to finish third place in a game | first = Andy | last= Chalk | date = July 31, 2017 | accessdate = August 1, 2017 | work = [[PC Gamer]] }}</ref> and ''[[Pokémon Go]]'' (which used location spoofing to simulate the movement of a real person in response to viewers' commands).<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2016/7/12/12167120/twitch-plays-pokemon-go-stream | title = Twitch Plays Pokémon Go is of course a thing | first = Paul | last = Miller | date = 12 July 2016 | accessdate = 12 July 2016 | work = [[The Verge]] }}</ref> Similar Twitch Plays have been used for taking care of a virtual pet [[Tamagotchi]],<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2015/12/10/9885230/twitch-plays-tamagotchi | title = Can Twitch users keep a precious Tamagotchi alive?| first = Andrew | last = Webster | date = 10 December 2015 | accessdate = 10 December 2015 | work = [[The Verge]] }}</ref> and installing [[Arch Linux]] onto a virtual machine through text commands entered one letter at a time.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pcworld.com/article/3001378/operating-systems/after-beating-dark-souls-and-pokemon-twitch-is-installing-arch-linux.html | title = After beating Dark Souls and Pokemon, Twitch is installing Arch Linux | work = [[PC World]] | date = 4 November 2015 | accessdate = 10 December 2015 | first = Chris | last = Hoffman }}</ref> Inspired by this last application, another experimental "Stock Stream" was started in May 2017 to allow Twitch viewers to vote every five minutes on the trading of stocks on the [[New York Stock Exchange]] from an initial $50,000 fund provided by the stream's developer, placing some rules to avoid triggering any financial regulations.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/2017/5/30/15714850/twitch-plays-stock-market | title = Twitch is currently playing the stock market with one man’s $50,000 | first = Julia | last =Alexander | date = May 30, 2017 | accessdate = May 30, 2017 | work =[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref>
The term "crowdplay" has been ascribed to similar games where the actions of the crowd directly influence the gameplay.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/252439/Beating_Dark_Souls_Hard_Designing_Twitch_Plays_Dark_Souls_SUPER_hard.php | title = Beating Dark Souls? Hard. Designing 'Twitch Plays Dark Souls?' SUPER hard. | first = Chloi | last = Rad | date = 1 September 2015 | accessdate = 3 September 2015 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] }}</ref> [[tinyBuild]] used the "Twitch Plays" model to release ''[[Punch Club]]'', holding back release of the game until either a preset date or completion of the game running via a public "Twitch Plays" stream.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/263215/TinyBuild_locks_its_latest_game_behind_a_Twitch_Plays_wall.php | title = tinyBuild locks its latest game behind a 'Twitch Plays' wall | first = Alex | last = Wawro | date = 7 January 2016 | accessdate = 7 January 2016 | work = [[Gamasutra]] }}</ref> ''Punch Club'' later added the ability for viewers to bet on in-game fights using virtual ''Twitch.tv'' currency, following a similar betting model used by Oxeye Game Systems for ''[[Cobalt (video game)|Cobalt]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pcgamer.com/punch-club-getting-a-free-expansion-the-dark-fist/ | title = Punch Club getting a free expansion: The Dark Fist | first = Angus | last = Morrison | date = 26 February 2016 | accessdate = 25 July 2016 | work = [[PC Gamer]] }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.pcgamer.com/you-can-now-bet-on-cobalt-bots/ | title = You can now bet on Cobalt bots | first = Angus | last = Morrison | date = 16 January 2016 | accessdate = 25 July 2016 | work = [[PC Gamer]] }}</ref> [[Telltale Games]] premiered a new "crowd play" feature for its adventure games starting with its 2016 ''[[Batman (2016 video game)|Batman]]'' game, allowing stream viewers to vote on selected decisions within the game.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.inverse.com/article/18696-telltale-batman-crowd-play | title = Fans of Telltale's 'Batman' Video Game Are in for a Big Surprise | first = Steve | last = Haske | date = 25 July 2016 | accessdate = 25 July 2016 | work = [[Inverse (magazine)|Inverse]] }}</ref> In January 2016, Twitch created a specialized directory for various "Twitch Plays" streams, with their VP of Developer Success Kathy Astromoff stating that the company has recognized the growth of similar experiments, and enabling such experiments to be easily found by its userbase.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.gamespot.com/articles/twitch-plays-gets-its-own-directory-on-twitch/1100-6433795/ | title = "Twitch Plays" Gets Its Own Directory on Twitch | first = Mat | last = Paget | date = 14 January 2016 | accessdate = 14 January 2016 | work = [[GameSpot]] }}</ref> Further, in March 2016, Twitch announced a new "stream first" initiative to help developer create games that are aimed for integration of streaming and chat atop more traditional gameplay, basing the format on the prior success of ''Twitch Plays Pokemon'' streams.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pcgamer.com/twitchs-stream-first-initiative-integrates-chat-with-a-new-wave-of-games/ | title = Twitch’s "Stream First" initiative integrates chat with a new wave of games | first = Tim | last = Clark | date = 14 March 2016| accessdate = 14 March 2016 | work = [[PC Gamer]] }}</ref> [[Amazon.com]], which acquired Twitch in 2014, developed the [[Amazon Lumberyard]] game engine that includes direct support for Twitch streaming to allow viewers to influence games via the associated chat, taking cues from the popularity of "Twitch Plays".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.polygon.com/2016/2/9/10949002/amazon-lumberyard-free-games-engine |title = Amazon rolls out Lumberyard, an entirely free game development engine | first = Owen | last = Good | date = February 9, 2016 | accessdate = February 23, 2017 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref>
Another homage, Fish Plays ''Pokémon'', surfaced in August 2014 as part of a [[HackNY]] hackathon. The stream, which consists of a [[fishcam]] in which the position of a [[betta fish]] in a [[fish bowl]] is used to control ''Pokémon Red'', peaked around 20,000 concurrent viewers.<ref>{{cite web|last=Newhouse|first=Alex|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/you-can-now-watch-a-fish-play-pokemon-on-twitch/1100-6421568/|title=You Can Now Watch a Fish Play Pokemon on Twitch|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=8 August 2014|accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-08/07/fish-plays-pokemon | title = There is a fish playing Pokemon on Twitch right now | first = Chris | last = Higgins | date = 7 August 2014 | accessdate=8 August 2014 | work = [[Wired UK]] }}</ref><ref name=cnet-fishpokemon>{{cite web|title=This is real: 20K Twitch users are watching a fish play Pokemon|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/this-is-real-20k-twitch-users-are-watching-a-fish-play-pokemon/|website=CNET|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref>
A Helix Fossil emote with the shortcut "PraiseIt" was later made available as a Twitch chat emote in celebration of the original ''Pokémon Red'' run.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitchemotes.com/emote/38586|title=PraiseIt|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>

It debuted on TPP after being in development for almost eight years.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hEaUQJP_p1A Pokémon Prism - Official Trailer] (video description)</ref> |- | style="width:1%; background: #FF8C00;" | | ''[[Pokémon Sun and Moon|Pokémon Sun]]'' | 18 November 2016 | 2 December 2016 | 13 days, 22 hours | |- | style="width:1%; background: #0080ff;" | | ''[[Pokémon Sun and Moon|Pokémon Waning Moon]]'' | 13 January 2017 | 26 January 2017 | 13 days, 11 hours, 37 minutes | Used a modded, more difficult version of ''Pokémon Moon''. |- ! rowspan="9" scope="row" style="white-space: nowrap"|Season 4 | style="width:1%; background: #ffff00;" | | ''[[Pokémon Yellow|Pokémon Chatty Yellow]]'' | 12 February 2017 | 24 February 2017 | 11 days, 19 hours | The third anniversary run. Uses a modified version of ''Pokémon Yellow'' centered around Chatot, which utilizes scripting to take quotes from users in the chat to replace in-game dialogue in real time.<ref name="kotaku-chatot">{{cite web|title=For Its Three Year Anniversary, Twitch Plays Pokémon Gets Its Most Ridiculous Game Yet|url=http://kotaku.com/for-its-three-year-anniversary-twitch-plays-pokemon-ge-1792295552|website=Kotaku|accessdate=13 February 2017}}</ref> |- | style="width:1%; background: #000000;" | | ''Pokémon Dark Graystone'' | 24 February 2017 | 13 March 2017 | 2 weeks, 3 days, 4 hours, 4 minutes, 57 seconds. | Uses a modified version of ''Pokémon Gold''. Played as a sidegame like ''VC'' and ''Ultra''. |- | style="width:1%; background: #D3D3D3;" | | ''Pokémon Ash Gray'' | 13 March 2017 | --- | TBD | Uses a modified version of ''Pokémon FireRed'' based on the events of the ''[[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon]]'' anime. Played as a sidegame. |- | style="width:1%; background: #ffb6c1;" | | ''Pokémon Blazed Glazed'' | 8 April 2017 | 25 April 2017 | 16 days, 16 hours | Uses a modified version of an existing modified version of ''Pokémon Emerald'', known as ''Pokémon Glazed''. |- | style="width:1%; background: #ffffff;" | | ''[[Pokémon Black 2 and White 2|Pokémon White 2]]''{{ref|1|[n1]}} | 3 June 2017 | 20 June 2017 | 16 days, 18 hours, 11 minutes | Randomized. |- | style="width:1%; background: #DAA520;" | | ''Pokémon Pyrite'' | 12 August 2017 | 26 August 2017 | 14 days, 7 hours, 58 minutes | Uses a modified version of ''Pokémon Crystal'' featuring increased difficulty and other changes. |- | style="width:1%; background: #3CB371;" | | ''Pokémon Theta Emerald EX'' | 30 September 2017 | 15 October 2017 | 15 days | A modified version of ''Pokémon Emerald'' which features increased difficulty, 721 Pokémon as well as various other changes from later generations. |- | style="width:1%; background: #7CFC00;" | | ''[[Pokémon Red and Blue|Pokémon Green]]'' | 15 October 2017 | --- | TBD | Badly translated bootleg. Played as a sidegame. |- | style="width:1%; background: #CC6600;" | | ''[[Pokémon Ultra Sun and Ultra Moon|Pokémon Ultra Sun]]'' | 25 November 2017 | 8 December 2017 | 13 days, 4 hours, 7 minutes | |- ! rowspan="9" scope="row" style="white-space: nowrap"|Season 5 | style="width:1%; background: #ff0000;" | | rowspan="2" | ''[[Pokémon Red and Blue]]'' | rowspan="2" | 12 February 2018 | rowspan="2" | 27 February 2018 | rowspan="2" | 14 days, 1 hour, 50 minutes | rowspan="2" | A dual run in which ''Pokémon Red'' and ''Pokémon Blue'' are played simultaneously. Unlike the previous dual run, inputs are split between the two games and users can choose to input specifically for one game or let it alternate between them. |- | style="width:1%; background: #0000ff;" | |- | style="width:1%; background: #C0C0C0;" | | ''[[Pokémon Heart Gold and Soul Silver|Pokémon Storm Silver]]'' | 14 April 2018 | 4 May 2018 | 19 days, 3 hours | A romhack of ''Pokémon Soul Silver'' in which all Pokémon from up to the fourth generation are available as well as various other minor changes. |- | style="width:1%;background: #FD4098;" | | ''Pokémon Sweet'' | 4 May 2018 | Ongoing | TBD | A romhack of ''Pokémon FireRed'' with "candified" Pokémon known as PokéSweets. Played as a sidegame. |- | style="width:1%;background: #B18B43" | | ''Pokémon Bronze'' | 9 June 2018 | 18 June 2018 | 8 days, 8 hours, 21 minutes | A romhack of ''Pokémon Gold''. |- | style="width:1%;background: #D32B45" | | ''[[Pokémon X and Y|Pokémon Y]]''{{ref|1|[n1]}} | 11 August 2018 | 26 August 2018 | 14 days, 11 hours, 26 minutes | Randomized. |- | style="width:1%;background: #ffcc00" | | ''[[Detective Pikachu]]'' | 8 September 2018 | 10 September 2018 | 1 day, 22 hours, 47 minutes | |- | style="width:1%;background: #C3DA78" | | ''Pokémon Flora Sky'' | 13 October 2018 | 29 October 2018 | 16 days, 2 hours, 42 minutes | A romhack of ''Pokémon Emerald'' featuring an original story and Pokémon from the fourth and fifth generations. |- | style="width:1%;background: #FFEB3F" | | ''Hypno's Lullaby'' | 30 October 2018 | 12 November 2018 | 1 week, 5 days, 23 hours, 55 minutes, 43 seconds | A romhack of ''Pokémon FireRed'' based on the [[creepypasta]], Hypno's Lullaby. Played as a sidegame. |} From ''Platinum'' to ''Black 2'', the stream showed a second game, ''Pokémon Stadium 2'', alongside the main game. Unlike other games, inputs for Stadium 2 were chosen at random and were not controlled by the chat. Instead, players on the chat were given virtual currency that could be used to place bets on the outcome of Stadium 2 matches.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2014/05/05/twitch-plays-pokemon-gambles-with-pokemon-stadium-2/|title=Twitch Plays Pokemon gambles with Pokemon Stadium 2|publisher=Joystiq|author= Mike Suszek|accessdate=19 May 2014}}</ref> After ''Pokémon X'' concluded on 1 August 2014, a similar system was implemented, with ''Pokémon Battle Revolution'' taking the place of Stadium 2, as it added more features such as better graphics. This time, instead of inputs being entirely random, players who bet on the current match could vote on which move would be used by their team each turn; the system would randomly choose one of the bettors' choices, but players who had placed higher bets had a higher chance of their move being chosen.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} The developer has created a modded version of ''Pokémon Battle Revolution'' known as ''Pokémon Battle Revolution 2.0''. It is meant to fix glitches and add various improvements such as additional battle arenas.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} During the interim, the stream showed ''[[Harvest Moon GB]]'', ''[[Pokkén Tournament]]'', ''[[EarthBound]]'', ''[[Robopon Sun]]'', and save states of the first four runs in reverse order.

== Notes == {{refbegin}} # {{note|1}}This game was randomized, using a [[pseudorandom number generator]] to change the predetermined Pokémon, items, and moves. # {{note|2}}This game was played using a [[ROM hack]] of ''Pokémon Black 2'' called ''Pokémon Blaze Black 2'' and featured the ability to obtain all Pokémon available within Generation V as well as other gameplay tweaks.<ref name="Pokémon X" /><ref name="Blaze Black 2 Changes">{{cite web|url=http://projectpokemon.org/forums/showthread.php?26326-Pok%E9mon-Blaze-Black-2-amp-Pok%E9mon-Volt-White-2|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140714110106/http://projectpokemon.org/forums/showthread.php?26326-Pok%E9mon-Blaze-Black-2-amp-Pok%E9mon-Volt-White-2|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 July 2014|title=Pokémon Blaze Black 2 & Pokémon Volt White 2|first1=Drayano|date=11 November 2012|accessdate=12 July 2014}}</ref> {{refend}}
